DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR W. P. O'CONNOR

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House of the death on Friday, 18 September, of Mr William Paul O'Connor, a member of this House for the Divisions of West Sydney, from 1946 to 1949; Martin, from 1949 to 1955; and Dalley, from 1955 to 1969. As a mark of respect to the memory of Mr O'Connor I invite honourable members to rise in their places.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members having stood in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

—Will the Treasurer agree that, if the Government had shown political courage and followed Senator Walsh's advice to cut expenditure further, this would have accelerated the pace of adjustment on our external account and prevented Australia from going further down the Argentinean road?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh has never put any views in the Cabinet to the line that outlays should be cut further. The fact is that this Government has brought the starting point deficit down since June 1986 from around $8 billion to zero. As such, that is the biggest change in fiscal policy of any country Australia may be compared with; that is, $5 billion cuts on recurrent outlays, $2 billion on receipts-mainly from base broadening and from compliance-and $1 billion on assets. That is the reason why, following the collapse in the terms of trade in late 1985, early 1986, the Government has made such a rapid response and that is why the response has been greeted so enthusiastically in the markets.

ANSWER.PARA: I also refer the honourable member to his own Press statement of a week ago in which he said that he would be re-examining the funding elements of the Liberal tax cuts and their introduction. He said that it is just not a matter of credibility; it is a matter of sensible economics. I put a statement out saying that of course he was dead right. It is worth recalling that the impact of the coalition's policy would have been to have wiped out $2 1/2 billion of base-broadening measures and to have added $2.7 billion in this current financial year from tax cuts, which would have left us with a deficit of $6 billion. Under this Government it is zero. I do not think one can put the point more eloquently than to say that this Government has faced all its responsibilities. Senator Walsh was making no criticism of the Budget aggregates. All he was doing was giving us a run again on his long run views on certain expenditure programs, views which have been broadly rejected in the Expenditure Review Committee over eight sessions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of Opposition claims that farm incomes are set to decline this financial year? Can the Minister advise the House of the outlook for the rural sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition spokesman on primary industry asked me a question last week and pointed out that in Budget Statement No. 2 it was stated that farm production was down by one per cent. He implied that, therefore, the farm sector was in quite a bit of trouble. I thought that was just an innocent mistake, and I did point out the reason why farm production was down. I see that the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Murray keep on repeating that, so I think it is in order that I just correct them and point out to members of the House information that has been around for quite a while.

ANSWER.PARA: I refer particularly to the Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, a publication by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. It shows very clearly that the index of the real net value of rural production this year is expected to be up by 27 per cent. It is the value of production that counts, it is the farm income figures that count, not necessarily the volume of production itself. All that appears in the Budget Papers is that there will be a drop in the volume of production. I pointed out last week why this was so. We are all aware that the gross value of rural production for the wheat industry is down substantially, but we are also aware that it is up by about 33 per cent for wool and up by quite a large amount, some 23 per cent, for livestock products. All those figures are publicly available and on the record. More importantly, the paper from the Bureau shows that we have had the first improvement in almost a decade in the terms of trade for farmers.

The main economic problem for farmers for quite some time has been interest rates. The economic management of this Government has got and is getting interest rates down. The 90-day bank bill rate is now 11.4 per cent. It was about 19.5 per cent last August. The prime rate is now between 14.25 and 14.5 per cent. The people who do not understand that interest rates are coming down as a result of this Government's policies have another think coming. I just stress the benefits of this Budget for the farm sector. We have here the simple proposition that we are getting the economy right, and nothing so affects real net value of rural production and the real incomes of farmers as good economic management. We have almost a balanced Budget; we are bringing interest rates down; we have the lowest deficit to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio in 35 years; we have the largest real decline in outlays in at least 35 years; we have growth up from 2 to 2 3/4 per cent; we have inflation coming in at 6 per cent, which is getting towards the average rates of all our competitors and, as I have said, interest rates have dropped to the extent that they are now more comparable with those of the countries with whom we compete on world markets. The family assistance package introduced by my colleague the Minister for Social Security will also help low income farmers. That is a marvellous measure for those who are in real trouble in the bush.

On the revenue side, we now have a system that is much fairer. What we are doing is managing Australia's second economic recovery in four years, following the mess we inherited and the terrific terms of trade disaster in 1985-86 of some 10 per cent and in 1986-87 of some 5 per cent. Farmers now face terms of trade improved of 3 per cent. The fiscal imbalance is fixed, public debt as a share of GDP is falling, the inflation imbalance is being fixed and we are bringing interest rates down, and the real net value of rural incomes expected this year should increase by 27 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to comments by the Minister for Finance, who has stated that there are 200 programs which cannot be justified on social justice or equity grounds but which will not be abandoned because the Government does not have the political courage to do so. Does the Minister agree that there are programs within his portfolio which cannot be justified on social justice or equity grounds and, if so, which are those programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of this Government's record with respect to social security, I think not only Senator Walsh but also all members of this House would recognise that the Government has been concerned to ensure that proper restraint is exercised, that there is improved targeting in relation to those programs and that there are real improvements in the level of assistance, particularly in the area my colleague has referred to-low income families. Not only has that been the policy of the Government but, over a number of Budgets, the Government has delivered that policy in relation to improvements in the targeting of programs.

ANSWER.PARA: On the other side of the ledger, in terms of restricting payments where we do not believe that there is the greatest need, no government has shown more political courage than the present Government. Indeed, no Minister for Finance has better demonstrated, over successive Budgets, a commitment to ensuring that our programs are delivered in the areas of most need. We were able to make a tough decision like our decision on the assets test and, despite the opposition from the rabble on the other side of the House, to carry that decision through to ensure that millionaires did not receive age pensions and that the people who were the most in need received those payments. Similarly, we made a decision in relation to the reintroduction of the means test for the over-70s.

We have to remember that Senator Walsh, as I understand it, was referring to comments that were made at the time of the National Conference last year. Since that Conference, we have made decisions, both in the August Budget and then in the May statement, which have the effect of improving the targeting in those programs. So we are not talking about some kind of abstract theory. We are not speculating about what we might do if we got the opportunity to add substantially, as the Treasurer has suggested, to a prospective deficit. Rather, we are making decisions that will ensure greater fairness and equity and will ensure that the people who really are in poverty receive substantial assistance. That has been the policy of the Government and that will continue to be the policy of the Government in the future.

In answer to the honourable member's question, of course the Government is prepared to be rigorous in its examination of all social security programs. There will be no variation in the policies that we have adopted in the past and all programs will each year be under the scrutiny of the Government. I think Senator Walsh is concerned to achieve progressive scrutiny but, ultimately, fairness and equity. If there is a term that is not in the lexicon of the Opposition, it is the term `fairness and equity'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs. What is the estimated number of coal miners who face retrenchment as a result of industry restructuring? What are the elements involved in the Prime Minister's recently announced package of $8m to assist retrenched coal miners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is broadly agreed within the industry, by both unions and employers, that restructuring of the industry will involve the retrenchment of about 3,000 coal miners. The package as announced by the Prime Minister involved the sum of $8m. That package is similar, in measures of unit costing, to those provided recently under assistance packages to the heavy engineering and textile, clothing and footwear industries. This basically comprised wage subsidy, formal training and relocation allowances. It has to be borne in mind that, unfortunately, in those areas where relocation will be necessary, vulnerable mines, essentially in areas which have already suffered some retrenchment--
—Have you lost your place?

—No, I have not lost my place. The restructuring that has gone on in the mining industry has already created high levels of unemployment. The elements involved in this package include an expansion of relocation assistance, because many miners will not be able to find employment in those areas in which they were previously employed. I am proposing to visit these mining areas affected.

ANSWER.PARA: The package will be administered by the Commonwealth Employment Service. It is important, given the number of people involved and the particular problems of miners who are facing retrenchment, that they are dealt with-as I am certain they will be-with both sensitivity and an awareness of the problems facing families who have to move from areas in which employment opportunities are poor and the housing situation is such that they will be selling their houses on a buyers' market. In many cases they will have to move to areas in which they will pay maximum prices for houses. I am grateful for the assistance from those members who represent electorates that are affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Will he confirm that each of his Ministers has full ministerial responsibility for the department which he or she is sworn to administer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sincerely thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question because it is important. I say that I thank him against the background of what I thought, and still believe, was the constructive response of the Opposition to the changes that I announced earlier this year. It is appropriate, in light of any uncertainty that emerged last week, that there be a complete clarification. So in that sense I do thank him for his question. Let me make it quite clear that there was no contradiction, as honourable members opposite may have thought there could have been, in anything that was said by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. Let me make it clear to the Leader of the Opposition what the position is; a Minister, having been sworn to administer a department, is responsible jointly with the portfolio Minister--
—And severally.
—For that administration, and must be so--
—Jointly and severally?

—Jointly and severally are responsible for the administration of that department. However, there is in place-I want the Leader of the Opposition to understand this; I think he does-a sensible administrative arrangement whereby a portfolio Minister asks the Minister to concentrate his or her attention on certain functional areas. I think the Leader of the Opposition would understand that. If questions outside those areas are asked of Ministers, the Ministers may need to refer matters to the portfolio Ministers or seek further information. Ministerial arrangements announced on 14 July do not affect, therefore, the normal representational duties in the other chamber.

ANSWER.PARA: So that it may be quite clear that there is no contradiction or difference involved between anything that was said last week and what I announced in my statement on 15 September, I remind the Leader of the Opposition that in my statement to the House on 15 September I said:

Portfolio Ministers are ultimately responsible for the administration of their entire portfolios and will be accountable to the Parliament for the overall operation of their portfolios. All Ministers, however, have a clear accountability within specific responsibilities allocated to them.
The Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support was reported on 18 September as saying:
The idea that I have direct responsibility for this matter is incorrect.
The Minister was talking there about the allocation of specific areas of responsibility between the portfolio Minister and himself, but that does not--

TALK.START.PARA: —You used the word `administration'.
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will not interrupt.

—I assure the Leader of the Opposition, and I do so gladly against the positive response that he gave before, that there is this overall responsibility shared by the two Ministers for the portfolio as a whole. But administratively, in terms of the division of their specific responsibilities-`you will look after that, that and that'-in that sense the answer by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support was appropriate and not inconsistent with what the constitutional position obviously requires.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME: FUNDING ARRANGEMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the House of the reason for the 76 per cent increase in funding for the battle against acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and can he indicate the proposed allocation of those funds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. It relates to one of the more important health challenges this country is facing. We have increased AIDS funding under this Budget by some 76 per cent, noting that 583 Australians already have been diagnosed with full AIDS. Of that number, 319 have died. The present expectation is that the numbers diagnosed will double every 10 months and a conservative estimate for 1990-91 is a cumulative total case load of some 3,000. Of the $20.5m that we have allocated, $9.5m goes directly to the States for cost shared programs. That has been adjusted this year to give particular weighting to those States with the heaviest demands, based partly on the total number of AIDS cases. This weighting means that New South Wales, which has by far the highest proportion of AIDS cases, has been particularly well treated as a result of this. The new formula is an attempt to link the needs of the States to the funding they receive. In addition we have doubled the amount of money on AIDS research, taking it to $3m. Funding for the National Reference Laboratory has also been increased so that the Laboratory can continue with its important work in evaluating AIDS technology and the changes that take place in AIDS technology.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, as we have no vaccine and no cure and as education must remain at the very forefront of our activities, for the National Advisory Committee on AIDS budget this year we have put aside $4m for information and education. Because behaviour change is so important and community groups can play a major role in this, there is another $3m for national community grants. This is all part of a co-operative campaign between the Commonwealth Government and the States to fight what is, as I have said before, one of the biggest public health challenges we have faced in this country since the Second World War.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. In view of the claim just confirmed in the answer to the honourable member for Deakin that the document he referred to last week in answer to a question from me was part of the tender documents, which appears to be in conflict with what Senator Evans has said, will he table the tender documents, including the document to which he referred, so that the matter can be resolved?
—No, I will not, but I will confer with Senator Evans concerning this matter and review the situation to ensure that any concerns that the Leader of the Opposition has can hopefully be allayed.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Will there be any savings or any loss of services in the closing of the Midway Migrant Centre and the welcomed re-opening of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government decided in the Budget process to reduce migrant-on-arrival accommodation stock to a level commensurate with forecast demand from immigrants. The network has the capacity to accommodate some 3,500 people at the moment, but needs to provide only some 1,500. In Victoria, capacity far exceeds the demand from clients and is to be reduced to a more realistic level. Occupancy at the Midway Centre is 650 people as of June 1987 and is now well below the Centre's capacity which stands at 1,200. It is continuing to decline. Using the Enterprise Centre instead of Midway is an efficient way of meeting the reduced needs. The Enterprise Centre is a much more modern complex than the Midway Centre and offers significant economies in operation, particularly in relation to food services, housekeeping, maintenance and general overheads. Enterprise was closed in October 1985 as part of the rationalisation of migrant centre operations with an intention to redevelop the Centre as self-contained accommodation at a later date if needed. Operational cost savings in the order of $1m per annum will be achieved in Victoria as a result of the Government's decisions. Should redevelopment of the Enterprise Centre proceed, the cost of redevelopment could easily be met from operational savings arising out of the move from Midway to Enterprise. The decision to move operations to the Springvale area is strongly supported by the population and housing forecasts for metropolitan Melbourne recently released by the Victorian Minister for Planning and Environment. The report clearly indicated that the growth in population, employment, accommodation and community facilities through the year 2000 will be in the south-east corridor which embraces the Springvale area.

—I refer the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support to media reports that the Department of Aviation had warned only 11 days after the Coastwatch contract was awarded to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd that this company was `out of its depth' with such a contract. —I direct a question to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer to continuing concern in the community about the sale of toy nasties. Will the Minister advise us as to what action has been taken to ban the sale of these unacceptable toys? Has he taken any steps to involve State Ministers for consumer affairs to co-ordinate a nation-wide campaign against the sale of these products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for his question. He is a member who has shown a continual interest in consumer affairs matters. I inform the House that the toys that the honourable member has talked about are called victim toys. These are toys which have become available on many shelves around Australia and they usually show children with some form of physical injury, mutilation or deformity as a result of violence, hence the name victim toys or, as they have often been called in the Press, toy nasties.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Trade Practices Act at the moment, it is difficult to show that these toys will or may cause injury, and so I have set up a committee under the Consumer Goods Advisory Committee. This Committee is chaired by the Hon. Ray Reynolds, QC, a former judge of the New South Wales Supreme Court. He, along with other members of the community, including people from the Australian Toy Association, the Advertising Standards Council as well as psychologists and other parent bodies, will look at the issue of psychological damage, as distinct from physical damage, as this is what the Trade Practices Act currently refers to. The problem is that under the Trade Practices Act it is difficult to address this issue directly. There needs to be further investigation of it. I have taken the step of writing to most toy retailers and distributors in Australia to ask them to look at their shelves and at the toys they have there, and to accept some sort of voluntary steps to look at an area which is of concern to the broad community. I hope that that will be done.

In the meantime, other State Ministers, principally Peter Spyker, the State Minister in Victoria, have shown concern about the matter. Mr Spyker has also set up a committee to look at it and at a broader range of issues in this area. Nonetheless, I hope that the committee that I have set up will be reporting to me late in November, and then further action will be considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to section 51 (xiii) of the Constitution, which expressly excludes the Commonwealth from making laws to control State banks. If the identity card legislation is ever proclaimed, what legislative power does the Commonwealth intend to use against a State bank which declines to put the ID number on its clients' accounts and thus creates itself the `Zurich' of Australia?

—I would need to check the law on that, but what I find amusing about the underlying basis of all these questions is why the Opposition has chosen to take such a dogged attitude to what is essentially a simple numbering system to provide computer efficiencies to deal with fraud and taxation abuse. The $1 billion which the Government has forecast as proceeds from this system is a very large figure indeed. I just remind honourable members that when the Government had the consumption tax on the table in 1985, the fiscal dividend or yield from the consumption tax was $1.5 billion. We have yielded $2.5 billion from the base broadening measures and a further $1 billion from an ID card. I am at a loss to understand why the Liberal Party of Australia should take an attitude that an instrument against tax avoidance which can be used to deal with taxation fraud and social security fraud ought to be resisted, all on the basis of some phoney and trumped up idea that we have an internal passport or, alternatively that--
—I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. On a matter of relevance, I asked a very specific question of the Treasurer and he has avoided it completely.
—The honourable member knows full well that the Chair has no authority to tell the Minister how to answer the question.
—He should answer the question.
—If the honourable member for Moreton does not cease interjecting, the Chair will deal with him.

—I said that I would check the law. I cannot, off the top of my head, recall the position. But in respect of the system this mock indignation on the part of the Opposition about denial of civil liberties is really stretching credibility to a point where those opposite are quite happy apparently to see losses to the revenue and fraud on the social security system and not do anything about it.

—I address my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can he outline to the House the progress that has been made on mill rationalisation within the Queensland sugar industry? Having regard to the rationalisation of the Babinda, Mourilyan and Goondi sugar mill areas, can the Minister give details to the House of the Queensland Government's stamp duties with respect to the purchase of the Goondi mill and indicate to the House what stamp duty is payable to the Queensland Government on the transfer? Further, can he indicate whether the Queensland Government has given any indication that it will forgo such payment in support of the sugar industry? If not, can he seek such support from the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. Since we introduced the sugar mill adjustment package jointly with the Queensland Government, the sugar mill adjustment committee has been processing several propositions before it, the most successful being the Goondi-Babinda rationalisation. The major reason that the sugar mill adjustment committee and the Government acted so quickly here was that the Goondi mill was up for sale by CSR Ltd. Although that was not greeted with a great deal of equanimity in that sugar-producing area, the rationalisation made a lot of sense from many points of view.

ANSWER.PARA: We have put funds in, and we came to an arrangement with the Queensland Government. But there is now some request for additional funds. Of those additional funds, quite a large amount is explained by the Queensland Government's requirements for the duties referred to by the honourable member. At this stage we are talking about some hundreds of thousands of dollars, and I guess that that will be subject to some ongoing correspondence between the Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland, Mr Harper, and me.

In terms of other rationalisations, one of the other mills up for sale by CSR was at Pleystowe. There was an enormous amount of activity at the mill level well before the sugar mill adjustment package was put together or the mill adjustment committee was set up. Various private consultants were brought in. It always looked as if in the Pioneer Valley there was a great chance for rationalisation, to get mills handling something like a million tonnes of cane or more a year. We are very close now to having a package together there. It will be submitted to the sugar mill adjustment committee.

As for the other areas, my colleague the honourable member for Hinkler is very well aware that some funds have gone forward for the Isis mill, or will be doing so shortly. We have been handling or looking at the problems of the Rocky Point mill. They are subject to ongoing correspondence between the Queensland Government and me. Other propositions are being advanced, but in terms of rationalisation, I think this money will be very effectively spent, so that the industry is in a better position to handle the economic problems that face us in the years ahead, in the Babinda area and prospectively in the Mackay area. The honourable member for Leichhardt has taken a very close interest in this matter right throughout. He has been particularly of a mind to make sure that not only the sugar farmers are taken care of, but also the mill workers, particularly, displaced mill workers. In terms of funds being made available to that committee, a sum is being made available to the displaced workers which is largely due to the good offices of the honourable member for Leichhardt.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the Prime Minister said today that Senator Walsh had assured him he did not know the media were present when he spoke about the Government's Budget strategy in Perth at the weekend? Is it a fact that Senator Walsh said at one stage during his speech that part of his speech was off the record, therefore indicating he knew of the presence of media representatives? Has the Finance Minister misled the Prime Minister, or has the Prime Minister misled the media?

—The answer to the first part of the honourable member's question is yes. In regard to the second part, there is no reference made to his saying that a part is off the record. But I make the obvious point that that is not inconsistent with the proposition that he did not know the media were present because one can talk to a group of people other than with the Press present in a way where one is quite prepared to let them go at will, or one can then say, `Look, there is something I want to talk about now and it is off the record'. I have no reason at all to believe that Senator Walsh has told me other than the truth. He told me unequivocally that he did not know the media were present. I have no reason to disbelieve him, but I make the point that if he did make the comment at some point that `this part is off the record' then that is not inconsistent with that proposition and obviously not inconsistent.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. I am sure the Minister is aware of the critical importance of adequate quality water supplies to this, the driest of continents. What information can the Minister provide on progress being made by the Government in the conduct of water research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say to the House that since the establishment of the Australian Water Research Advisory Council in June 1985 considerable effort has been directed by this Government to developing a strategy to strengthen the Australian water research program. That strategy is aimed at improving leadership and co-ordination in water research. At a research seminar here in Canberra last week there began a development of a statement on national water research needs and priorities. Under that strategy as well there is to be a strengthening of research capability through initiatives being carried forward by the national water research program. These include some 12 water research centres, a scientific merit program, a water research achievements award and a research fellowship scheme. These are designed to help attract students to careers in water research.

ANSWER.PARA: Additionally, we have moved to encourage investment in water research through the provision of incentives to the water industry itself to fund research by the industry's participation in partnership research programs-that is, that the industry itself become involved in expenditure on water research in the establishment of water research, centres of its own and, from the Government's point of view, by the provision of funds for higher priority research and regional problems, such as the Murray-Darling basin. Added to that is the need, I believe, for all of us-I think this matter transcends party politics-in the Parliament to improve community awareness and community understanding of the need for water research and the need to make more efficient use of that very valuable and limited commodity. To back that initiative with money, the Government has provided in this year's Budget some $5.8m, which is a 74 per cent increase on the expenditure last year. It compares with half a million dollars expenditure by the present Opposition prior to our coming to government. If we add to that $5.8m being provided this year the sum of $374,000 carried over from last year, this year in total the Government is providing some $6.2m to further water research, to strengthen activities in the industry and to assist the community to find adequate and quality water supplies.

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any matter of administration for which he is responsible.

This, of course, in substance is part of the same question raised during Question Time by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Madam Speaker, as you will recall, last Friday we had a debate on the coastal surveillance contract. In the course of that debate the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support said as part of his defence-these are the words he used:
I want to say that this matter was not directly within my area of responsibility . . .

So we have a Minister saying that here is a matter arising within this Department but it is not within his area of responsibility. That statement highlights the problems that have now arisen from this new structure of ministerial responsibility which was outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on two occasions, on 14 September and 15 September, and on a third occasion when he answered a question in Question Time today. Madam Speaker, it leads to this matter upon which the House, with respect, would find it an advantage to have your guidance; that is, to which Minister are honourable members to address their questions-to the Cabinet Minister, if I can call him that, the super-Minister, or to the non-Cabinet Minister, the junior Minister? More generally, but I think more importantly, the question arises of whether junior Ministers in this House are responsible to the Parliament, or not, for the administration of the whole of the department. Of course, as we all know, they are sworn in as Ministers to administer a department and the question is whether they are Ministers here responsible to the Parliament for the administration, not of part of a department but of the whole of a department.

Until the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support made his statement on Friday, I think we all assumed that the non-Cabinet Minister, the junior Minister, was responsible for the whole department. We assumed that-or at least I assumed it-for two reasons. The first, as we all know, is that the Constitution provides for the appointment of Ministers to administer a department of state, not half a department or two-thirds of a department, but a department and only a department of state. Of course, it is common ground, we all accept now, that we may have two or more Ministers administering the same department, but they must all, it would seem, administer the whole of the department. It is not the case, it would seem, that the department can be split up between different Ministers.

The second reason why we assumed that junior Ministers were responsible for the whole of the department was that the list of Cabinet Ministers which was tabled by the Prime Minister on 14 September said that. If we take the example of the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, we see beside his name, under the heading `Department Administered', the Department of Transport and Communications referred to. To the reader of the list tabled by the Prime Minister it is apparent, and it is the only thing that can be apparent from it, that he has been sworn in to administer the Department of Transport and Communications-and, one might add, presumably the whole of that Department. If he was not, he is not a Minister and of course other things flow from that.

All of that background-and I am grateful for your indulgence, Madam Speaker-leads up to this: I seek your guidance on whether all Ministers are responsible to the Parliament for the whole department that that Minister is sworn in to administer, or only part of it-as the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support seems to believe is the case with him, otherwise he would not have been saying the other day that here was a matter, a subject of contentious debate in this Parliament, which was nevertheless a matter which according to him he was not responsible for. Of course, this is exacerbated in this case because the specific functions given to him and listed in the Prime Minister's statement include operational aviation matters.

Finally, Madam Speaker-as I say, I am grateful for your indulgence thus far-the question is this: standing order 142, as we all know, enables questions to be put to Ministers on any matter of administration for which the Minister is responsible, so when standing order 142 allows such questions to be put to a Minister on those matters for which he is responsible, does that mean all of the matters within the department which the junior Minister has been sworn in to administer?

Madam Speaker, this is an important matter upon which your guidance should be sought. It is important because it goes to the very root of our responsible parliamentary democratic system and it is important because it is based on a Constitution which really does not know these notions of ultimate responsibility, or special responsibility, to which the Prime Minister has been referring. The Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) has put out a form of Press release in which she refers to her special responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member has explained the case pretty well.

—Again, Madam Speaker, and I will conclude on this point, our Constitution knows nothing of any notion of special responsibility. We have people who are Ministers, so are they responsible for departments or are they not? What we want to know, what I want to know, is this: are all Ministers sworn in to administer a department responsible for the whole of that department and are they to be treated as such in this House, or not?

—Before I call the Prime Minister, I point out to the honourable member for Menzies that it is no responsibility of the Chair to decide which Minister will answer any question. I call the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Speaker, and I thank the honour- able member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) for raising this matter. He did me the courtesy of indicating that he would be raising it. I had thought that essentially I had addressed in my answer to the question from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) the concerns that were in the mind of the honourable member for Menzies but, if not, let me in a sense repeat and add to what I said.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Menzies says that the Constitution knows no division. When we talk about what the Constitution knows, unfortunately in this life the Constitution does not have a voice that can speak for itself and we have to go through the very expensive process of approaching those in the honourable member's own profession, who charge highly for saying what the Constitution knows and says. Obviously, we have gone to members of the legal profession and we have received advice from them as to what the Constitution knows, to use the honourable member's rather mystical phrase. We have acted on the best advice that we got, and that advice is reflected in the statements that I have made to the House.

I suggest to the honourable member for Menzies-and I say this with great respect-that apparently he had no problem in understanding either the constitutional or the factual basis upon which we have acted until he heard the statements by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan). I suggest, with respect, that the Minister quite properly used the word `responsibility' in regard to the division that had been sensibly arrived at between the portfolio Minister and himself. The honourable gentleman said in his question that he could understand a situation where we could have two or more Ministers responsible for a department. Now obviously--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they do that in Argentina?

—Come on! The honourable member has gone from foreign affairs to economics and has enough on his plate now in just starting to understand economics without going back into the foreign affairs area. I am saying to the honourable member for Menzies that, if we were talking about two or perhaps three Ministers in a total portfolio area, good sense would demand them saying among themselves, `In regard to the handling of this portfolio I will take particular responsibility for these areas and you will take particular responsibility for those', and that is what is being done. In that sense the Minister was saying that that was not his particular responsibility. But that does not take from the fact that, in regard to responsibility for the administration of the portfolio as a whole, that is something which each of the Ministers is sworn to do.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in answer to the Leader of the Opposition earlier today, Ministers having been sworn to administer a department, as they have been, a Minister is responsible, jointly with the portfolio Minister, for that administration. That is clearly the case. It is totally in accord with the constitutional advice that we have received. The only difficulty that has arisen in the mind of the honourable member for Menzies is as a result of the language properly used by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support which reflected nothing more and nothing less than the fact that, sensibly, in order to conduct their affairs, in regard to this Minister it had been said, `He will have the responsibility for handling that and that'. That is what he said in the House. There is nothing in that statement by the Minister which is in any way inconsistent with what I have said to the House, with the constitutional advice that we have received and, most importantly, with sound administrative practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to speak briefly on this matter.
—I call the Leader of the Opposition.

—This is an important matter. Could I say at the outset, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) quite properly said in answer to my question, that there are features of the new administrative arrangements made by the Government that the Opposition supports. We certainly have no basic quarrel with the proposition that more than one Minister can be sworn to administer a department and we welcome the more progressive attitude now being taken by the law authorities in advising the Government on this matter. The difficulty that I have, and I think the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) has, is not with that basic proposition but with reconciling what flows from that. What flows from that was clearly spelt out by the Prime Minister when he said that the Ministers were jointly and-in answer to an interjection from me-jointly and severally responsible for the acts of their departments.
—That was your phrase.
—But the Prime Minister did not dissent from it.
—He accepted it.

—He said, `Jointly and severally'. Thus far I have no argument with the Prime Minister's explanation. My difficulty arises-I think the difficulty of the honourable member for Menzies arises-when the Prime Minister seeks to reconcile that with the claim made by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) that there are certain matters within the Department for which he is jointly and severally responsible, under his oath as a Minister, for which he has no direct administrative responsibility. The question that we ask is: where on earth does direct administrative responsibility for a particular matter finish and joint and several liability for the acts of his Department commence? I think the Prime Minister owes the House an explanation for where the one finishes and the other starts.
—Does the Prime Minister want indulgence to reply?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Madam Speaker. I do not know whether there is a wilful refusal to listen or just an intellectual incapacity on the part of honourable members opposite. I will for the third time attempt to make it clear to those who are either unwilling to understand or incapable of understanding. I think it is fair to say again, as I did to the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown)-and I am quite happy about its being raised-that I think the problem, if there is one, has arisen because of the use of language by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan). He was not, in making the point that he was making, quite directly and innocently, seeking to address the constitutional question of responsibility in the sense in which the honourable member rightly raised the question of that broad constitutional responsibility. He was referring to the arrangements that have been made between the portfolio Minister and himself in relation to the vast range of areas covered by the Transport and Communications portfolio. They have sensibly and intelligently sat down as colleagues, in just the same way that the Opposition would do if it were ever in government, which is unlikely in the foreseeable future, and said, `Now look, I will cover this area, you will cover that area and let us go about our business'. What the Minister was saying, in using the word `responsibility', was that in that sense that area was not his responsibility; it was the responsibility of Senator Evans. It was quite innocent of and unrelated to the broad and proper question that the honourable member for Menzies raised.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not retreat or resile from the proposition, the basic constitutional fact, that there is a constitutional responsibility which is shared by the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support for the whole Department. He was saying no more and no less than that, in relation to the arrangements that he has with Senator Evans in terms of handling all the functional responsibilities, that he will look after that, that and that, and Senator Evans will look after the other areas. It was in that sense that he was talking about responsibility. That is so clear that I am surprised that a man of the degree of learning in the law which the honourable member for Menzies has cannot grasp it. I think from the genial smile upon his face that he now does.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs

Any proposal to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concerns ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's Veterans.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to:
Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of Veterans and their families.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
