DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Government Programs

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke Government to show political courage to cut programs that are not justified on social justice or equity grounds to stop Australia going further down the Argentinean road.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in an astonishing but truthful speech at the weekend, said essentially-I use some paraphrasing to reduce it-that this Government is a cowardly, gutless government that presides over scandals and rorts but masks them by overselling to disguise our slide to banana land. There are a number of things that can be said about Senator Walsh's extraordinary remarks. Firstly, he told the truth, secondly, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is agitated about the truth being told but, thirdly, he will do little about it. Fourthly, Senator Walsh's remarks totally support the Opposition's claims, for he has blown the cover on both this Government and its Budget. Fifthly, and most importantly, Senator Walsh has stated clearly the perilous state of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh's points were, firstly, that the Government lacked the political courage to abandon unjustified programs; secondly, that he could think of 200 such programs; thirdly, that the new Parliament House building is `a scandal'; fourthly, that a sum of $650m is being spent on a new Brisbane airport for which `there is no functional need'. That is one with which we would not agree and there are a number of others too. Fifthly, he advocated an inheritance tax and said that the only reason the Government was not implementing it was not because it did not believe in an inheritance tax, but because it would be blocked by the Senate. There is nothing wrong in principle with that; it is just that we would oppose it.

Sixthly, he said that that child care should never have been taken away from the private sector. Seventhly, he said that there was no justification for providing such a high level of subsidy to only 17 per cent of the children under five years of age. Eighthly, he said that there were strong arguments for reimposing tertiary education fees; ninthly, that the Budget might have been `oversold'. And, tenthly, that there was a need for Australians to hold down consumption expenditure and build up savings. And is he not right? Eleventhly, he said that if people were encouraged to spend rather than save, Australia could be sent `further down the Argentinean road', that road that it appears we are already embarked upon. Twelfthly, he said that if it gets much further it could well be `irretrievable'.
Those remarks are from the man whose name accompanies that of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the front of all official Budget Papers. I remind honourable members that the Budget Statements are:

Circulated by the Honourable P. J. Keating, M.P. Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia, and Senator the Honourable Peter Walsh Minister for Finance for the information of honourable members on the occasion of the Budget 1987-88.

I think honourable members would agree that Senator Walsh would be in a position to know. I think he has a bit to do with these documents. What today was the response of the Prime Minister? Firstly-this will not surprise honourable members-he said that it was all the fault of the media. I will give the House his exact words: `It's a massive media beatup'. Secondly, he said that the Minister did not know that he was going to be publicly quoted. Pick up the gun at home, load it, aim it, fire it, and see how you get on in court using that defence, old son. He did not know that the gun was loaded! Thirdly, the Prime Minister said that it was a private forum. There is a fundamental point about this. No one has denied that he said these things; it was just that he said them publicly.

TALK.START.PARA: —He told the truth.

—That is right. The question arises: is it true or not? He said it and I assume that he meant it. It certainly flows from his August statement when he wanted the Government to target 13 areas to be reduced. It really is an abject reflection on the cynicism of this Government-and dare I say it of this Prime Minister in particular-that the truth cannot be told publicly. Fourthly, the Prime Minister also said-and he started to edge to it as the Press conference went on-that the comments were unwise. Then he alleged, as the Treasurer did here, that they only involve the recitation of a 1986 anecdote. There are two comments at least to be made about that: he made at least 10 other points that had nothing to do with the 1986 anecdote and, if he did not think that the anecdote was relevant to all he said, why did he use it.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifthly, and interestingly enough, pushed by the media, the Prime Minister eventually conceded, but only in regard to this interesting alleged anecdote, that Senator Walsh came `close to breaking Cabinet solidarity'. Close! He positively embraced it with a bear hug, it seemed to me, certainly in terms of the other matters not directly related to the alleged anecdote.

That was the Prime Minister's response, but what should his response have been? Clearly, he should have sacked Walsh. Walsh should resign. Having lectured his colleagues on political courage, he should resign. If he does not, he should be sacked. It was a former Labor leader and dear member for Melbourne, who once said in remarks in this place and elsewhere, `Back him or sack him'. Of course, if one backs him, one must be agreeing with what he said.

I am not just making this up. Because of the total confusion in the mind of the Prime Minister about ministerial responsibility elsewhere, I decided to go back and look at the Cabinet Handbook that he issued in glossy print. It has his signature on it. It says that it is correct as at 4 November 1983, and it has not been changed since then. I shall just quote a few of what it calls `Cabinet Conventions and Principles':
Collective responsibility
2.1 The convention of the collective responsibility of Ministers for Government decisions is central to the Cabinet system of government . . .
2.2 Decisions of the Ministry are binding on all Ministers . . .
2.3 All Ministers are expected to give their support in public debate to decisions of the Government . . .
2.8 Public statements by Ministers: It is inappropriate for Ministers to accept invitations to speak or to comment publicly on matters outside their portfolios-
this has a relevance to the Treasurer's portfolio-

in circumstances which may involve disagreement-or which are likely to be construed as amounting to disagreement-with the conduct of another portfolio, without the prior concurrence of the appropriate Minister or the Prime Minister.
Did Senator Walsh have it? If not, he is in breach. To underline that further, in the Foreword the Prime Minister talks about adherence to the rules and principles. He says:
Adherence to them strongly supports the principles of collective decision making and collective responsibility.
I seek the co-operation of Ministers and officials in ensuring adherence to the Cabinet procedures laid down here.

I do not need to quote David Solomon's recent book commenting on this Cabinet Handbook, or a book by a lecturer in law or general studies in the University of New South Wales, Richard Lucy. One can go back to Dicey, the fount of wisdom on collective responsibility. I will use the phrase used by David Solomon. What these words that I read out were directed at was really a formal way of expressing the idea that all the members of the Cabinet must sink or swim together. If one does not like it, one gets out. If one disagrees with what the Minister said and he said something at variance with the Government, he should be sacked. One is either fair dinkum and abides by the enforced rules or one does not. This Government simply jettisons the rules.

Behind that question of ministerial responsibility, every member on this side of House knows that there is something even deeper than whether a particular Minister can scuttle away from what he said in a moment of honesty. What Senator Walsh has done is blow the cover of all the Treasurer's rhetoric, particularly when he said that the Budget was oversold. `Oversold' is a polite way to say that Australians were conned by a beat-up, that is, by misrepresenting it. The Budget was not balanced. We said that last week and Senator Walsh knows that it was not. Far worse, he shares the fears that we in the Opposition hold that the Government is `complacent'. That is the very word that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) used in describing the Budget last Tuesday night; he said that the Government had been complacent. Too right it is complacent.

That means that we have lost another year in the battle against our economic problems. The cost of the Treasurer's complacency is another year of higher taxes, another year longer accumulating foreign debt at the rate of approximately $1 billion a month, complacency in the face of a huge net foreign debt, a large current account deficit, continued low investment in plant and equipment, continued high rates of wage and price inflation, continued high rates of interest, abysmal productivity, continued high rates of unemployment and an underlying Budget deficit, all taking us `further down the Argentinean road'. Indeed, as Senator Walsh also said, `If it goes much further it could well be irretrievable'. This Prime Minister dismisses the remarks and, more importantly, hides the truth from the Australian people.

Last Tuesday's Budget offered a golden opportunity to address our problems-and Senator Walsh knows this. If the Government had `the political courage' to cut spending further, more resources would have been released from the non-tradable public sector to the tradable goods sector-an essential impetus to export growth and import replacement. This is the Government, after all, which for the first time in Australia's history lost our AAA international credit rating; yet even this does not shake it from its `complacency'. Senator Walsh has exposed this Government for the fraud that it is-fraudulent figures and fraudulent rhetoric. But who suffers as a consequence? Does Keating? No. Does Hawke? No. Does Walsh? No. Not on your life. Only the Australian people suffer. The Government is taking them down-in the words of its Minister for Finance-`the Argentinean road', and will not even tell them.

Last week I said that the Budget figures were illusory and that Keating was pulling the wool over Australians' eyes. I said that he was cooking the books with what these days is euphemistically called creative accounting. There is no doubt, flowing through all that Walsh said, that he agrees. A Liberal-National Party government would take our problems on head on. We would not waste the opportunity to cut government expenditure and we would give tax relief. We would balance the Budget with lower levels of expenditure and tax and we would therefore speed up the rate of adjustment-because we are not complacent. Above all, we would tell the truth.

Senator Walsh undoubtedly agrees with us that not only is the Government deceitful, using the word `oversold', but also that it is undertaking a very risky strategy with this Budget. We should think of that. Sure, it is risky. It is possibly risky for the Government. But what of the risks for Australia? I should not raise the question of the national interest, should I? After all, it mattered not to the Prime Minister that Senator Walsh told the truth. That it got out was his crime. Even that cannot move the Prime Minister to take the appropriate step of either backing him or sacking him. The Prime Minister implies that he has quietly and gently censured his Minister. Censured him! It seems like flaying him with a wet tissue. Why? For simply telling the truth.

Summing up this rather abject and grubby affair in which one Minister tells the truth and calls on his colleagues to show courage but when found out shows none himself, we reach the conclusion that Senator Walsh has blown the cover-and he knows all regarding the Budget. Secondly, he corroborates the Opposition's stance. More importantly, he has revealed the damage being done to Australia by this Government. The Prime Minister will not back Walsh. According to the Prime Minister, he was just indiscreet. The Prime Minister will not sack Walsh. Walsh will not resign. The Prime Minister, in the refuge of the scoundrel that he so often is, blames the media. By his behaviour, this Prime Minister is yet again shown as a weak, vacillating, compromising person who above all will not tell the truth and does not want it told.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —What staggers the Opposition is that this Government has been so extraordinarily successful in turning round the fortunes of this country which was left in such a godforsaken position by those opposite including, I might say, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), who in the dying, last, hopeless days of the Fraser Government was the Minister for Industry and Commerce. What he has to contend with is that, at that stage, we had unemployment at the rate of 10 per cent, inflation around 10 per cent and fiscal policy wildly out of control all as a result of flagrantly irresponsible policies pursued in the Budget a few months before which were all designed to produce electoral victory before Christmas. We all know that that strategy was wrecked and we all know that as a result of that electoral strategy being wrecked Australia was left wrecked with it and we, the Australian Labor Party, had to come in and attempt the great task of cleaning up the mess. Members of the Opposition cannot understand why and how we have been so extraordinarily successful. The fact is that we have been able to produce a balance Budget on this occasion, something which they, even in their wildest dreams, only promised they could do three years down the track. That is only if one believes some of the wild fantasies which they put into their pre-election figures on fiscal policy. Three years down the track they were going to balance the Budget; this Government produced it this year at once.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there has been a lot of scurrilous abuse of my colleague and, I might say, good friend the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). I would be staggered to find anyone in this country-anyone certainly on this side of the House-who would agree that Senator Walsh lacks guts. They might say lots of things about Senator Walsh, but one of the things they will not say about Senator Walsh is that he lacks guts. Senator Walsh has been the Minister for Finance since the 1984 election. This is not necessarily an easy thing for me to say, but I would say that Senator Walsh has been the best of the Finance Ministers this country has had. During the period that he has been Finance Minister, he has been absolutely resolute about two things; that is, forcing Ministers and the Government collectively to justify, line by line, every item of expenditure. It may well be that on some issues he would challenge a particular expenditure; that, after all, is his role. A good Minister for Finance will always-indeed, in my view-challenge every line of expenditure. Whether or not this can be justified in the context of the Expenditure Review Committee, or in the context of the Cabinet is a matter for collective decision-making and, of course, takes into account certain political considerations as well as those in broader fiscal policy or other particular criteria that one might want to apply to any particular line of expenditure. But it is his task to challenge expenditures of Ministers individually and of the Government collectively. Having been involved in this process for all of the time that this Government has been in office along with him, I might say that Senator Walsh has done that in a painstaking way which has required a great amount of discipline upon all Ministers in this Government. We go through a very exacting process as we make our decisions about expenditure. There has been absolutely no lack of political courage as we have undertaken that task.

Just to give honourable members an example of the way in which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has quite outrageously taken out of context what Senator Walsh said or was purported to have said over the weekend, let me just put this in the context of the time at which the anecdote was made and where we are at the moment. The anecdote that he referred to was made by him or recalled by him at the time of the Labor Party conference in June 1986. Since that time we have had two Budgets and one expenditure statement in May this year. In June 1986 the prospective deficit for the forthcoming year was in excess of $8 billion. That is what we had to look at when we sat down to finalise the 1986-87 Budget-$8 billion. What have we produced? Two years later we produced a deficit of zero. There is $8 billion of accountable, absolute political courage. Not only did we do it, but we also got re-elected on the basis of the political courage that we demonstrated in producing that astonishing result. That is the greatest turnaround in fiscal policy that has ever been seen in this country and, I dare say, has been rarely paralleled in any other country of our kind anywhere around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does Walsh disagree with you?
—Because he made the statement two years ago, you dummy.
—Order! The Minister should not refer to other members in such a provocative approach and tone.
—He was recalling an anecdote he gave two years ago.
—I thought he said it at the weekend.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting. The honourable member for O'Connor might resume his seat unless he is raising a point of order.
—I just came in to sit down.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.

—The central tenet of the position of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is that there are 200 programs about which we lack the political courage to do anything. The statement about 200 programs goes back to two years ago when there were perhaps 200 items of expenditure or savings options which the Government had to look at. We have looked at them, we have dealt with them and they add up to $8 billion. That is to be put in sharp contrast.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor shall not interject that these are lies and he should withdraw that comment.
—I did not say that. I said it is up from $5 billion this morning.
—That is what it sounded like. I apologise.

—Let me explain that. The honourable member for O'Connor was not in the House when I first made that remark. What I was referring to was that when we sat down to finalise the 1986-87 Budget the prospective deficit was in excess of $8 billion. The prospective deficit now is zero. There has been a $8 billion turnaround. That is $8 billion worth of courage, courage that can be added up, courage that has actually been rewarded by an electorate which understood what needed to be done and which appreciated the courage and the dedication that we-and might I say, Senator Walsh-were prepared to bring to this question.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of recurrent expenditure-that is where the $5 billion comes from-$5 billion worth of expenditure has been taken out of recurrent outlays during that two-year period. That has happened because the Minister for Finance, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and I and other members of the Expenditure Review Committee have painstakingly gone through our expenditures line by line, added them up and made a judgment as to whether those programs were justifiable. We made the judgment that there was $5 billion worth of additional expenditure there which the country could well do without if it was going to make the adjustment which was necessary in our current circumstances. In order to get to the $8 billion there are, again, the base broadening measures in the taxation system.

Let us recall that almost all of those base- broadening measures, which now account for some $2 1/2 billion of additional revenue, were opposed by Opposition members not because they did not agree with them but because they lacked political guts to support them. We know that if John Howard had his way he would embrace nearly all of those option A tax measures. He used to advocate half of them publicly and God knows what he believed privately. Of course when it suited him, when there was the prospect of an election looming, he abandoned them all because he thought he might be able to grease his way to power by offering some superficial attraction to populism. That was not the course for us; it was not the course for the Treasurer; it was not the course for the Minister for Finance. We decided to take the tough options and I reject out of hand any suggestion that we have lacked the political courage to address the circumstances of our times.

I said at the beginning of my speech that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition at the time of the changeover in 1983 was the Minister for Industry and Commerce. He more than anyone should know the devastation that was wrought by our predecessor's industry policy. Our manufacturing industry had become woefully uncompetitive internationally and he knows it. In the last several years, under the guidance of policies pursued particularly by Senator Button, we have had to turn that situation around. So rather than losing hundreds of thousands of jobs in manufacturing industry we are now increasing jobs and with those jobs we are picking up markets not only in Australia but also overseas. That is the task we have set ourselves and from which we will not be deflected by any beat up from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or anyone else.

When an election looms it is always easy to pad out Budget figuring in order to make the situation look better than it is. I raise this matter in answer to the suggestion by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that this Budget is not what it purports to be. Let me take him back just a few short years to 1982-83 when there was a $2 billion difference between the outlays predicted at the time of the Budget in late 1982 and that which actually occurred in the middle of 1983. There was a $2 billion discrepancy in the outlays of the last Budget of the Fraser-Howard Government. As well, revenue was understated by some $0.8 billion, with the result that we had a massive deficit blowout of $2.8 billion in the last Budget that Mr Howard was responsible for under the Fraser prime ministership. That has to be seen in the context of the Deputy Leader's suggestion that our Budget does not add up and will not add up. Our record of accurately projecting Budget outlays, revenue and deficit size is unrivalled. Indeed, in only one year was there a discrepancy and that was a direct result of the massive collapse in the terms of trade which confronted Australia during 1985-86. As a result of that we embarked upon the scrutiny of taxation and Government outlays in order to ensure that that would never again happen to Australia, that Australia would face up to and go through the adjustment process which we are now going through.

If there is anything about what Senator Walsh has said that I would like to make much of, it is that what he is drawing attention to and what I think the Government as a whole wishes to draw the country's attention to is that the task is not over and we have to continue to be as resolute as this Government has been in the course of its term in office, most particularly over the last two years, if we are to work our way through these problems. There is no suggestion that people can lie back in the traces as a result of the progress we have made to this point. Australia still has a task to confront and this Government will do everything it can to ensure that circumstances exist in which that can be confronted. That is the reason why I have been engaged in looking at the whole question of properly preparing the work force in terms of skills for the challenge that exists. Despite having an unemployment rate of around 8.1 per cent, about two percentage points lower than when we came to office, there are still skills shortages because our predecessors were totally negligent in the way in which they dealt with these questions. They did not care whether there were skilled workers to undertake the tasks which Australia could and now will undertake in order to work our way out of the difficulties in which we find ourselves.

I conclude on a final point. On the matter of political courage, I take honourable members back to the circumstances of the last election. All of our expenditure cuts and our taxation propositions were laid out for the electorate to judge. What did we get from Johnny Howard? We got only promises to get rid of those taxation measures which now bring in $2 1/2 billion. He thought they might have been a bit unpopular. Not only that, there was another $2 1/2 billion worth of unspecified spending cuts. If ever one wanted an example of absolute, unqualified, political gutlessness or lack of courage it was that, going to the electorate and saying, `Here are the cuts but I will not tell you where they are because you might not like them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. Before I call the honourable member for Richmond I mention to honourable members on both sides that members are expected to refer to other members, Ministers and office holders by their title rather than their name. In the last two contributions there was a tendency to refer to individuals by name rather than by title. I trust the honourable member for Richmond will not continue in that vein.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sure that you would agree, along with all of my colleagues, that I strictly observe the Standing Orders of this place, and also the precedents that have been set by your rulings. I will adhere to those precedents in the course of my remarks this afternoon.

—I remind the honourable member for Richmond that I have not set any precedents; I have not given any rulings. I have drawn his attention to the fact that honourable members should refer to members, Ministers and office holders by their title.
—Surely, Mr Deputy Speaker, and you have allowed certain remarks to go unchallenged also.

—I also remind the honourable member for Richmond, if he wishes to press the point, that initially the remarks of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition went unchallenged. I thought that to provide balance in the debate it was fair to allow the Minister to continue along the same line. I would draw the attention of others to that fact if they continue to do so.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will arrange for someone to move that I be granted an extension of time. I felt very sorry for the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), when he made his remarks this afternoon because he, like many members of the Hawke Government, agrees with the comments of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). The Minister is reported in today's Press as proposing that the Government reintroduce university fees.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: it is not in order for the honourable member to speculate about my views on anything and I would rather he did not, because he is wrong.
—Order! I call the honourable member for Richmond.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. If it is going to be one of those afternoons, let us really go for it. The Budget has been referred to as some sort of economic miracle. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is walking around the place describing it as historic. Let me tell honourable members opposite that it is historic because the Treasurer of this country is gambling his political future and the economic future of Australia on this Budget. I am talking about some of the things that are contained in this Budget, how it is balanced and how the Government has oversold it, to use the words of Senator Walsh. It certainly has been oversold; it has been turned into a media spectacular. When one looks at what is behind the Budget one can see what prompted Senator Walsh to make his outburst in Western Australia on Saturday. Nobody with any sense of economic credibility could resist making some comment, some protest, about what this Government, this Treasurer, has done to the Australian people and their possible future.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is operating in an economic circumstance whereby our country has a foreign debt of $110 billion and rising, it has a current account deficit of $10 billion per annum and it is not likely to come down in the next two or three years, it has 9 per cent inflation and 8.5 per cent unemployment, and it has its lowest rate of private investment in productive capital for almost two decades. In the face of this the Minister, who is now leaving the chamber, has the nerve to suggest that this is a responsible Budget, that the Government has addressed the economic problems of our country and that the Treasurer knows what he is doing. None of those things is true, and Senator Walsh knows them not to be true. That is why he made his comments. This country would be better served if Senator Walsh were Treasurer and the Treasurer were sacked. That is the option that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) confronts right now. He must sack either Senator Walsh or the Treasurer, because one of them is fundamentally wrong. We cannot have that sort of difference of opinion if we are to maintain Cabinet solidarity and the principle of collective Cabinet decisions as the basis for our Government in this country.

Let me explain, for the benefit of those honourable members in the Australian Labor Party who do not have the economic knowledge of Senator Walsh, exactly what the Treasurer is doing with this Budget. This Budget is based upon continuing foreign capital inflow, massive public sector borrowings and private sector borrowings, foreign equity and portfolio investment, and real estate investment. When we have those things we can continue to live beyond our means and we can avoid the necessity for fiscal responsibility. The incentive for foreign capital inflow is based on a low Australian dollar and high interest rates, but that is the essential problem on which the Treasurer is gambling. Capital inflow is forcing the Australian dollar up and our interest rates are coming down because of the increase in the money supply and because of the media oversell following his Budget. When the dollar rises and interest rates come down and perhaps there is some crack in the confidence of the Treasurer's economic management-a crack created by the comments of Senator Walsh in Western Australia this weekend-we will come to the crunch. If we do not have that continuing foreign capital inflow we will suddenly have to confront economic reality in this country. We have to confront the facts: we are living beyond our means and this Government's Budget shows no fiscal responsibility. It provides no incentive whatsoever for accelerated structural adjustment. Heaven only knows that is what our country needs. Our competitiveness is based on a weak dollar, not the essential productivity of our industries.

The Treasurer has produced a Budget with mirrors. We have seen examples of how he has achieved his $27m deficit. It is a direct result of the sale of the farm. He has sold a billion dollars worth of Australia's assets. It is a direct result of the Reserve Bank of Australia's foreign exchange profits. Its trading in foreign exchange and trading in the Australian dollar have produced profits which have been included in the Budget. A part of that is as a result of the Treasurer's approach to managing the economy, as a result of his approaching the whole thing with confidence so that from time to time the Reserve Bank can operate in the foreign exchange market and can produce these profits that go into his Budgets and make sure they are balanced.

But what we are really talking about is the future of our country. We have to decide whether we want a government that will show fiscal responsibility, and not only fiscal responsibility but also responsibility to the future of Australia. The Treasurer has financed this Budget by massively increasing government tax revenue. In five years government revenue has increased by 75 per cent. There are many people in the galleries here today who are on family budgets. They understand how difficult it is to balance a budget because, unlike governments, they cannot go into deficit perpetually; they have to achieve a family budget which is essentially balanced. They can use Bankcard from time to time but eventually they have to come up with expenditures that equal their income. But how many family budgets have increased by 75 per cent in the past five years? We have to ask how the Government increased its income by 75 per cent. It did so by increasing taxes and charges. In last year's Budget the Government magnanimously offered some tax cuts, spread over two fiscal years. Notwithstanding that, it still increased government revenue by 75 per cent.

The question everybody should be asking is: what sort of tax cuts would have been available had this Government cut its expenditure? In the last election campaign members of the Government ran around the country saying that fiscal expenditure could not be reduced and that the Opposition parties could not provide the tax cuts they were offering. The Opposition is saying that had the Government shown fiscal responsibility, had it cut back on waste and eliminated duplication, had there been, as we have said, the sort of responsibility shown that this country needs in order to avoid becoming the Argentina of the future, we would have been able to have massive tax cuts-not the tax cuts which the Treasurer has offered, not tax cuts which do not do anything for the average family, but tax cuts which would in fact help.

Notwithstanding that we have had some sort of Claytons tax cuts, the Budget Papers produced by the Treasurer and Senator Walsh indicate that income tax revenues are projected to increase by 9 per cent. That is how much they will go up this year, after the tax cuts. If we bring that back to the average family, how many average families in Australia today can count on getting a 9 per cent increase in their disposable income, the income they have to spend after they have paid tax to the Treasurer? Yet this Government, talking about its fiscal responsibility, has brought in tax scales which will still give it a 9 per cent increase in its income tax revenues.

The reality is that Senator Walsh was right. Every word he said directs a challenge to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister. The Government has to address the question of who is correct-the Treasurer or Senator Walsh. The Government can have only one of them in its Cabinet and it is about time, after the gobbledegook we have heard in this place today about ministerial responsibility, that we got a definitive statement from the Prime Minister and he decided which one of them will continue-the Treasurer or the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. We cannot have such a conflict within a government, and a government cannot have such a conflict and expect to have the respect of this Parliament or the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House reject the proposition that has been put forward in this matter of public importance today. During this discussion I will try to focus, just from the point of view of our perspective of the Opposition, on where a debate like the one we have had today is taking us. This Parliament is supposed to be about policies; it is not really supposed to be about personalities. So let us look at the continuing approach taken by those on the other side of the House and examine whether they have started to derive an approach towards policy development.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we listened to Opposition members attack Senator Walsh and call for his sacking, and all the other stuff they have gone on about. But nowhere in the contributions made by both honourable members opposite who have spoken in this debate was there a single suggestion about an alternative policy direction to that which has been brought forward in the Budget. That is the Opposition's direct failure. It has failed to perceive any alternative policy and that is what is seen by the people of Australia. There is nothing new about this. Just 2 1/2 years ago the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), as Leader of the Opposition, was known to be light on economics but high on public relations and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the failed Treasurer, was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and leading economic spokesmen. We have now had a 180-degree turnaround. The failed Leader is now the economic spokesman and the failed Treasurer is now the Leader of the Opposition.

In all that deck chair changing and swapping we have had the Queensland experiment. As a result, what has been going on with policy development? That is the question I want to have a look at. Underlying all this there has been a shift in policy and there has been the development of an approach; and I would like to flush out a bit of it. While we in the Government have been setting about doing things like reducing a $10 billion deficit to a near enough to zero Budget, members of the Opposition have been developing a policy approach which really needs to be looked at.

Today, this matter of public importance represents not just a complaint about Senator Walsh or the perceived inconsistencies in the Government's approach. It is really an attempt by Opposition members to say that in the Budget we have not cut enough and we have not cut in the right areas from their point of view. Let us examine that to see how the Opposition comes to this perception. Let us go first to what I call Valder economics. Let us not forget that just two years ago Mr Valder, the now failed President of the Liberal Party of Australia, made the Westpac tapes proposing that the Government make massive cuts and that they be in the area of social welfare. He was the first to expose that this is where the answers were. Then along came Mr McLachlan, the President of the National Farmers Federation. In Adelaide in April last year at the Liberal Party rural seminar he said that the coalition had not formed policies to provide a suitable alternative. That is what he understood, and he was pointing it out. Where was the National Farmers Federation during the recent Federal election? That was the big question asked. It has gone to ground because there was nothing there to support; and that is well understood by people on both sides of politics in Australia.

After the warning from the National Farmers Federation, out came what became known as the secret leaked document that flushed out the real coalition. Or should I call it the Liberal Party agenda? It was published on the front page of the Australian Financial Review on Monday, 23 March. The Australian Financial Review is not what one would call an Australian Labor Party propaganda magazine; it is the paper most broadly respected in the business community. In this secret leaked document we saw a call for a $5 billion spending cut. Where was it to go and why was the plan that it should be kept secret? It was proposed that it should be kept secret because, as the paper states, if the cuts leaked out there would be a general strike. Part of the secret agenda listed in 10 dot points was to prepare for a general strike. The Opposition was proposing in that agenda that we cut pensions and tighten eligibility; abolish all employment programs; impose a new personal and company tax; abolish the first home owners scheme; abolish the fringe benefits and capital gains tax-and so the list goes on. In the end the Opposition was preparing for a general strike. That was the secret agenda and that is what got flushed out.

During the election campaign it became very clear that the Opposition now has an economic policy. It is based on a cheap grab for votes, cutting taxes for the very well off. The Opposition's social strategy, first proposed by Mr Valder, was to cut benefits to those who were most in need in order to give to those who were least in need. That was its social policy and that is what this secret document is all about.

In between it all, if an Opposition is to function successfully as an Opposition it has to have some competent people who understand how the debits must equal the credits and who can actually put it together under pressure and make it work. What did we have during the recent election campaign? First of all, we had the honourable member for Bennelong, in his capacity as Leader of the Opposition, with his $500m error. We had Mr Stone, now the Deputy Leader of the coalition in the other place, saying that it was just a little matter, not a big factor. That $500m is $5.60 a week for every pensioner in Australia. They do not think it is just a little mistake or a little matter. But honourable members opposite do; they want to say that an error of $500m does not really matter. We have to look at their capacity to get the planning right. Tax cuts was the central plank of the Opposition's proposal at the last election. Out came the Leader of the Opposition, saying that the tax cuts would be brought in over one year. Out came Senator Michael Baume, in whatever capacity he was before being dumped from the front bench, saying on air in Tasmania that they would be phased in over three years. Honourable members opposite cannot get a policy right and they cannot get a strategy right. What is more, they cannot get their priorities right. If I remember the position of the coalition during the recent election campaign on the question of tax cuts, the Liberal Party had it as No. 1 on its agenda. It was the big ticket item-`We are going to deliver tax cuts'. Where were members of the National Party of Australia? They said: `Oh no, that is not quite right'. My colleague the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who is in the House, to his eternal credit was honest about this during the election campaign when he said, `We have it at about No. 3 on our priority list'. The reason for that was that his constituents knew very well that it was fairy floss, that it was not a top ticket item; and that is why the National Farmers Federation abandoned them during the campaign.

So where are we really at in this debate? Those opposite have been developing this alternative policy approach. It has been rejected by the people of Australia. I say to them in the kindest possible way: do not keep on about it. Have a look at a new approach. Do not keep trying to test the same old water because it is understood to be fraudulent and it is understood that it has to be rejected. They cannot come into this chamber and complain that there have not been enough cuts and that the cuts are not in the right area. They should look at their role as an Opposition and cease being the doom and gloom merchants of our economy. Our problems are difficult enough as it is without their wandering around being doom and gloom merchants, trying to talk down whatever confidence is starting to develop in our economy. They should stop opposing for the sake of opposing.

If those opposite are going to adopt the values of an Argentinean economy, at least they should try to be responsible about it. Leaving a $10 billion deficit was not responsible. Leaving 900,000 Australians in the unemployment queues was not responsible. Leaving young Australians without educational prospects was not responsible. We are tackling the hard questions, and we are tackling them in a responsible way. I suggest to the honourable member for Kooyong that, if he wants to bring into this chamber a matter of public importance proposing this sort of approach, he ought to go back to the foreign affairs area, grab a ticket to Buenos Aires and enrol himself in the University of Argentina for a degree in banana economics, because that is about where he is with the policies he is proposing today.
