PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed, covering the Privacy Bill 1986 and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to speak in support of this legislation, particularly as I have listened to a number of speeches by members of the Opposition. When the House debated this issue previously the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) were in the House. They said to one of my colleagues, `What did you do in the election? Did you campaign on it? Where do you stand on it?'. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, the identity card legislation and the consequential privacy legislation associated with it were the cause of the double dissolution. For my part, I say to the House that I campaigned very strongly on this issue. I not only issued a number of Press releases, but also the Australia Card featured prominently in the brochure that I used throughout the election campaign. In addition, I letterboxed some 5,000 households in Blacktown with a personal letter and a brochure in relation to the ID card issue. It is true that I did get a response from those people who were opposed to it. I received letters from two out of those 5,000 people. We have heard the furphy that somehow the Government has not capably campaigned on the issue or, even more ridiculously, that we should adopt the process that is used when a constitutional amendment is proposed-that is, the referendum process-in relation to this legislation, which requires no constitutional amendment. That is one of the more ludicrous suggestions that I have heard.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ben Lexcen was reported in my local paper, the Mount Druitt-St Marys Standard, as having addressed a meeting of small business people that was held at the Rooty Hill Returned Services League Club. The headline of the article is `The ID Card is evil-Lexcen'. Let me say that I have responded this week to his article. Essentially, the article is racist, emotional claptrap. Mr Lexcen's major concern seems to be that he has lived through the Hitler era and the McCarthy era. Let me respond to that statement. Those are two extreme examples of the Right. They do not have anything to do with our side of politics. Indeed, the concentration camp argument seems to be raised time and time again. Let me say that my mother's side of the family has certainly experienced regimes of both the Left and the Right. Regrettably, very few of my mother's relatives were able to escape the Germans in 1939. Those who did escape were finished off by the Russians. I think it is absolutely ludicrous to suggest that this system of number identification can be in any way compared to the processes of that regime. McCarthyism is something that we all condemn.

The inherent opposition to the ID card seems to do one thing: it seems to undervalue Australia's commitment to democracy and its preparedness to defend it. Mr Lexcen is some ways, I think, concedes this when he says, in effect, `I'm not worried about what this Government would do'-included in that statement is probably the Opposition-`what I am worried about is what will happen in 50 years time'. The Government has a responsibility for today and maybe tomorrow, but in 50 years time another generation will have the responsibility. Last week seven groups of school students from my electorate visited this Parliament. They came from primary schools and high schools. In 50 years time those students will be about 59 or in their sixties. I am confident-I have always been confident-that Australians will resist the sort of totalitarian, emotional claptrap that the Opposition raises about the potential danger of this card. I know that if honourable members on this side saw any government, of whatever persuasion, wanting to introduce such a process, they would resist it.

The argument is not about what the card will do now; it is about what the card will do in the future. The Opposition has been opposed to the ID card; there is no doubt about that. In the post-election period, certainly in New South Wales, in terms of getting the Opposition up and running in its opposition to the ID card, the Liberal and National parties have not had anything to do with it. It has really been commentators, like Alan Jones on radio station 2UE, with his extremist and emotional talk, who have really whipped up a frenzy. The Opposition has belatedly almost jumped on his coat tails, saying `Me too, we think it is important'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the Labor Party?

—Mr Jones hardly represents the Labor Party. Why would the Opposition, apart from the reason I have previously outlined, want to maintain its opposition, knowing the Constitution, knowing the conventions of this place, and knowing that there was a double dissolution over this matter? The answer is simple: it has traditionally maintained the civil liberties of those who wish to cheat and defraud the Commonwealth and put the burden on the decent, ordinary taxpayers of this country. The only people who will benefit from not having an ID card are tax avoiders. Mr Deputy Speaker, because of your chairmanship of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure and its inquiries into the Australian Taxation Office, you would know of the difficulties that the Taxation Office has in matching interest payments, dividend payments and tracking down property. I have seen the difficulties at first hand when the Joint Committee of Public Accounts investigated the acquisition of new computers for the Taxation Office. It is an immense job and the Office is not doing it well now. If one were to ask the Commissioner of Taxation, as we did during that inquiry, he would tell one that we need the ID card. In fact, I was naive enough to think that perhaps, given the way things were going at that stage, the Office would have been working on some alternative proposal. But he was quite adamant that the ID card was important if one wanted to stamp out tax avoidance and the lurks and perks that still remain in the taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: Who else does the Opposition defend? Of course, it is defending those who are abusing the social welfare system. Let me tell the House that I attended a meeting of the same small business people. With tears in their eyes they told me how terrible it was that they were forced to employ people who were on the dole and were continuing to receive the dole while working. I said to them, unequivocally, that I dislike and have no time for people who are working and who collect the dole, but I have even less time for those who employ them. I represent an electorate in which there are many people who are genuinely seeking employment and who would like the privilege of a job. But if we are to get them into jobs and get this economy right we must get away from the mentality of lurk merchants, tax avoiders, and those who abuse the social welfare system.

Who is the Opposition protecting? It is protecting the 50,000 to 60,000 illegal aliens. Any member on this side of the House will tell you that the matter that most constantly preoccupies his time in terms of constituency work is usually that of immigration. I, like my colleagues, try as hard as I can to get as many new citizens into my electorate in this great country called Australia. But I do not support illegal aliens because we have seen evidence that although they are not entitled to do so, they are overstaying the limit of their visas-if they have a visa-and they are collecting Medicare benefits; they are picking up benefits to which they are not entitled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Special benefits.

—Special benefits. The ID card is the only system that will track these people down. Opposition members talk about civil liberty and their concerns for it. They are not concerned about the civil liberties of the Australians who have to support the 50,000 to 60,000 illegal aliens. They are not concerned about the civil liberties of Australians who seek work but cannot obtain it because some people who are in work are receiving dole cheques. They are mostly concerned about protecting tax avoiders. I sum up the Opposition in this way: it is the party of the wealthy, the tax avoiders and the lurk merchants. That is the marketing niche which Opposition members have carved out for themselves; that is the niche which they will defend to their last vote in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate some of the points that I have covered. I campaigned very strongly in the last election. I got one of the smallest swings in the western suburbs of Sydney. I think that that was because, among other things, I campaigned so vigorously on the ID card. Mr Lexcen, a champion of the Opposition to the ID card, came to my electorate and used a blatantly racist argument. The Standard quotes him as saying:
Say in the year 2030 Australia might have a population of around 50 million, with 40 million Asians and 10 million Caucasians.
If that is not a racist argument, I do now know what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under the Standing Orders, as interpreted by Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice, is it in order to make accusations of this nature against an individual Australian other than by way of a substantive motion?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—According to the article entitled `The ID card is evil-Lexcen', Mr Lexcen said that in about 50 years time Australia might have a population of 50 million, with 40 million being Asians and 10 million Caucasians. He is quite happy and content to support a racist argument. I wonder whether the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) feels comfortable using a racist argument such as that.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member is not allowed, under the Standing Orders and according to Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice on the rules and interpretations of the Standing Orders, to come into this House and call individuals racists.
—As I said earlier, there is no point of order.
—I am quite happy to table the newspaper article. I seek leave to table it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Perhaps I should bring a couple of other newspaper articles to the attention of the House as they sum up what is happening in the ID card debate. The first appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday, 11 September.
—A very good article.
—It was a very good article, as the honourable member for Dobell mentions. He is a champion of the ID card and particularly privacy. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For emotional claptrap, it is hard to go past the present debate on an identity card. There has seldom been a subject on which there has been so much misunderstanding, so much misrepresentation and so much downright irrational fear.
That sums up the Opposition's case pretty well. The article continued:
You would think that no Australian had ever been given a number; that drivers' licences, passports, credit cards and tax file numbers still had to be invented.

TALK.START.PARA: —They probably don't have tax file numbers.
—That aspect is probably worth investigating. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Few of the vocal critics of the Australia Card seem to have thought through the potential for abuse in the use of licence numbers by law enforcement agencies, through credit card transaction slips which can provide card companies with a great deal of information about a person's behaviour and the vast amount of information that the Tax Office has on sources and levels of income and assets.

Much has been said about the security around the ID card and the computer that will house it. However, I have never heard an Opposition member stand up and ask the same question of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) about his Department's computer system. That system is an extensive one. It is not a proposed system; it is one that is up and working. Is there no concern for privacy for those who are currently on social welfare benefits? Are we preoccupied only with the wealthy or those who wish to avoid their fair share of taxation? Is this the standard, the level of hypocrisy, for which the Opposition is aiming? I am very concerned that the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd has developed a policy whereby it is very selective about its customers. To be even more frank and blunt, there are many people in my electorate with whom it refuses to open an account. I have never heard an Opposition member express concern about that.

The whole point about the ID card debate is that the information which the card will contain already exists. There is information which the Social Security Department, the Health Insurance Commission and the Australian Taxation Office already have. The big difference between this Government and the Opposition is that we are concerned about the individual's privacy. One of the principal features of the Australia Card legislation and its concomitant privacy Bills is that, for the first time, we are entrenching rights to privacy that do not exist now. In all of the civil libertarian argument that is going on about the ID card, where is the concern for privacy for the citizen as it exists now? I believe that the Opposition is being quite hypocritical in its stance.
I am not usually one to quote John Laws; but, for the benefit of the honourable member for Higgins, I will quote what he said as reported in the Sunday Telegraph:
That's what worries me so much about the ID card debate that is currently ripping the country apart.
The sheer hysteria being whipped up is based on pure misinformation, half truths and deliberate lies.

Those are not my words. I am not trying to defame anyone. Far be it from me to want to do that in this House. That was Mr Laws's view. I commend his article to all honourable members. His article contained a series of questions in an effort to debunk all the half truths, lies and hypocrisy. One of the questions was:
Will it be necessary to produce the Australia Card every time you withdraw or deposit money to your bank account?
The answer was:
Definitely not. The card will be used once only. To open a new account or to establish identity for an existing one.

The offering which I have put before the House is very selective. The Privacy Bill 1986 establishes rules of conduct called information privacy principles (IPPs) for the collection and retention of, access to and correction, use and disclosure of personal information about individuals. The IPPs will apply to Commonwealth departments and agencies. Interestingly, they are based on the Australian Law Reform Commission's report No. 22 entitled Privacy which was presented in December 1983. This is also consistent with Article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. What the opponents of the legislation have never suggested is what we should be doing to protect citizens.

I see that my time is rapidly running out. I reiterate that I am a very firm supporter of the legislation. The Government should not buckle. If it does buckle under to pressure, the only people who will suffer will be those decent, honest Australians who are overwhelmingly in favour of the legislation, those Australians who accept their fair share of the taxation burden and responsibilities as citizens. A lot of hysteria has been whipped up. In my own State, there is a firm commitment on both sides of the political fence to a driver's licence containing a photograph. That is to occur in New South Wales. They do not raise any objections to that. It already exists in Victoria. It has been most amusing to read some of the quotations from Prime Minister Curtin in the 1940s, but they ignore the massive change that has been taking place in the 1980s compared with the 1940s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot imagine how you can sit there, Mr Deputy Speaker, without tears forming in your eyes, having listened to what the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) said. He has the hide, the utter gall, to stand in this chamber and talk about the Opposition being hypocritical. We have just heard the honourable member for Chifley go to town, trotting out his care for the privacy of the ordinary Australian citizen. He says that the Government is concerned about the privacy of the Australian citizen. Let us look at least at what one prominent member of the Government says about privacy. I am talking about the honourable member for Bonython, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). In 1986 at the South Australia Australian Labor Party branch conference Dr Blewett said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say, as a socialist, that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists-
that is the Australian Labor Party, the Government-
on privacy because privacy in many ways is a bourgeois right-
he refers to privacy as a bourgeois right-
that is very much associated with the right to private property.

They are the Minister's words. So, how can any member of the Government come in here and say that we are hypocritical and not concerned about privacy? I will refer briefly to this morning's Sydney Morning Herald which reports:

The latest Auditor-General's report has detailed security inadequacies in both the Department of Health, under Dr Blewett, and the Department of the Special Minister of State, under Senator Ryan-the Government's two main promoters of the Australia Card.

Only last week we had the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan)-he is also the Minister for gaffs and foot-in-mouth-say in Question Time, `We are talking about the transmission of ID data by landline. It will be secure'. However, this article in the Sydney Morning Herald goes on:
An audit of the Department of Health found inadequacies in controlled access to computer facilities-
but the Government says that that information will be safe-
as well as problems with the Department's general security procedures.
The article quotes the Auditor-General's report as stating:
The latest findings suggest that, other than for basic perimeter security, the department has given relatively low priority to security matters.
The Government says, `Don't worry about the database connected with the ID card; it is secure'. It could fool me on that. The article in the Sydney Morning Herald goes on:
In the Department of the Special Minister of State, the Auditor-General reported:
Programming staff were not formally trained in relevant data security measures.
The Government says, `Don't worry about it; it is secure'. The article goes on to state that the Auditor-General found:
The functions of the data security officer were not being performed, and data security policies and procedures were not documented.

That is from a report of the Auditor-General. How much worse will it be once we have the ID card, which I hope we will not. The honourable member for Chifley referred to fear being generated. I would just like to come back to that point because I have a letter which was written by a person in Urunga in my electorate who had been going around talking to people about the Australia Card and inviting them to sign a petition against it. The part of the letter I would like to read is this:
The younger people up to the age of, say, 50 years-
and that is very encouraging for those of us who are about that age-

are keen to sign right across political lines. One woman said to me-I have voted Labor all my life but I am dead against this one-she signed greedily. Older people are scared and won't put their name on anything. This thing has generated so much fear and distrust and that alone is reason enough to abandon at once its imposition.
There is a great deal of truth in that. The opposition to the Australia Card is not coming just from the Opposition; it is coming from right across the Australian community.

I inform the House of a decision taken by the Anglican Diocese of Grafton which stretches from Port Macquarie to the Queensland border on the north coast of New South Wales. Last Sunday week the Anglican Synod adopted a motion from the Reverend Jim Nightingale of Kempsey. He said:

From a religious perspective, I have an identity which was given to me by God, and my fingerprints tell me that I am unique. As a Christian, I know who I am and I do not need the State to give me a synthetic identity.

The Reverend Jeff Murnain of Port Macquarie, in supporting the motion, stated that as Christians we are called to love justice; we are called to be watchmen. For this reason the church had a responsibility to make itself heard on this issue. He went on to say:

There is a need for more incisive debate. There is a need for the democratic rights of people to be exercised. The Card is more than bad legislation; it is clearly unpopular; it is potentially dangerous; it is inherently evil. I believe that we as the Church have a command from Jesus our Lord to caution the Government against an untimely, undebated, unpopular and dangerous introduction of this Card.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unworkable.

—It is unworkable indeed. The Anglican Synod voted to recognise the importance of a full and public debate on the proposed Australia Card legislation and to call upon the Federal Government to put the issue to a national referendum. Why not? Why not let the people have a say on this most vital of issues to come before this Parliament? What is the Government afraid of? Why will it not let the people have a say?

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to quote from the editorial in the 28 August 1987 issue of Computerworld, a magazine which is certainly knowledgeable about the issues we are talking about. It states:
In a recent televised debate, Senator Susan Ryan promised safeguards for the community, so that information surrounding the Australia Card would be at least as secure as the PINs-
personal identity numbers-
and account details contained within the banks' ATM-
automatic teller machines-

networks . . . there is no way that current network standards are capable of the level of security promised by Senator Ryan. Either the Government does not appreciate the difficulties in attaining this level of security, or it will not be able to live up to the promise, or it is being economical with the truth.

We know how secure it is. We know how many people in this House have had their piece of plastic gobbled up by the machines. Only in the last week the Commonwealth Bank and the Westpac Banking Corporation, I believe, had their computer systems go berserk and gobble up hundreds of people's cards, yet the Government is seeking to inflict more plastic on us.

I believe that the 23,000 legal practitioners, the lawyers in this country, should have the opportunity of putting their views. I will quote from a letter written to me and other members from Mr Darryl R. Williams, QC, the President of the Law Council of Australia. He says in part:

The Law Council has said, however, that it is opposed to the Australia Card legislation in its present form, and that its opposition is based mainly on its concern that the legislation provides inadequate protection of privacy . . .
That is what the Bill we are debating right now is about-privacy. The letter goes on:

The Council is also concerned that the Australia Card, as presently proposed, will involve a system of identification that could easily be expanded for use by all government departments and other data banks using the same identification numbers.
I return to Computerworld for a moment and to a story about `Teenyhackers'. The article states:
The US Secret Service sprang into action the other day, arresting nine teenagers from a Pittsburgh high school for fraud.

The juvenile hackers were alleged to have used home computers to gain illegal access to a credit authorisation centre, using the valid card numbers obtained to buy thousands of dollars of mail order merchandise.

Our man in Pittsburgh said the home hackers used relatively sophisticated techniques, including specially written software, to bypass security controls and navigate through credit records to get key information.
The President of the Law Council of Australia said:

. . . the Law Council views as objectionable the requirement that persons prove their identity before they can enter into a considerable number of quite common transactions and activities. This appears to the Council to involve an unwarranted restriction on the freedom that individual Australians have, and should have, to engage in ordinary activities and transactions.

I note in passing that the Government's attitude seems somewhat contradictory. On the one hand it argues that the information contained in the Australia Card and in the central data base will be limited and of such a character that there need be no concern about its being vulnerable to unauthorised access. On the other hand, the Government sees a need to establish a complex and costly system to protect that information-a system said to be the most secure available. It might be asked why such tight security is needed if the information held is as insignificant as the Government asserts.

The efficacy of the DPA will be dependent on subjective factors such as the provision of adequate funds for its staffing, and the skill, energy and philosophical attitudes of its members. Sufficient reliance could not be placed on the Agency to monitor and protect the rights of privacy which, by virtue of other provisions of the Bill, would become vulnerable.

There is a great deal more that I would like to say, but the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) will follow me shortly. I would like to state again, as I have in the House before, what I see as my basic philosophy in terms of politics, and that is that the Government is there to serve the people-not the other way round. We the people are not there to serve the Government, the Government is there to serve the people. The Australia Card is changing that about.

The honourable member for Chifley referred to what happened during World War II. I would like to say to the Parliament and to the people of Australia that in the 1930s, the people of Germany were not told of what happened, or so they said. After the war, they said, `We did not know about the concentration camps. We did not know about what the SS was doing. We did not know about all of those things'. Let the people of Australia know that this time, they are being told. The Australia Card is one way that we will lose our liberty and our freedom.
I just want to conclude by quoting from a speech that President Woodrow Wilson made in New York in 1912:

Liberty has never come from government. Liberty has always come from the subjects of it. The history of liberty is a history of resistance. The history of liberty is a history of limitations of governmental power, not the increase of it.
We must not increase the Government's power by giving it the Australia Card. We must reject it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak on the Privacy Bill 1986 and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986, I thank the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for his indulgence in allowing me to speak by splitting the available time with me. At the beginning of my remarks, I would like to refer to the comments made by the previous Government speaker, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price). As I understood it, he stated that the Liberal Party of Australia did not campaign against the Australia Card, the identity card, during the election campaign. I can tell him that he is absolutely wrong, and from personal experience I can inform the House that I campaigned on the issue in my electorate.
—So did I.

—So did the honourable member for Cowper. I am pleased to say that I had a 2 per cent swing to me, and this was one of the big issues in my campaign. Moreover, on 7 July, I put out a national Press release pointing out that in this double dissolution election because of the ID card legislation, members of the public, Australians, were being asked to vote when they could not get copies of the Australia Card legislation, at least in Melbourne. One could not get copies of the legislation in Melbourne before an election that had been called because of that legislation. It is a scandal. I put out that release, but none of the media published it anywhere in Australia to my knowledge. The media has a lot to answer for.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Chifley made some other comments. He referred to Hitler and said that it was outrageous to raise those arguments in this debate. I can say that one cannot trust any government of the extreme Right or the extreme Left. No government in a democracy should be given the power for people to take it over, whether they are of the Right or of the Left. Hitler and Stalin are to be condemned equally and one could imagine the even worse horror-there was horror enough-if people like Hitler and Stalin had had available to them the information that will be available to the bureaucracy and to government under the Australia Card legislation. The holocaust in Hitler's time would look like a Sunday school picnic, if his Government in pre-war Germany had had available to it by computer and on database the information that the Australian Government will have if this iniquitous legislation goes through.

I would like also to deal with the driving licence argument. Government members are saying, as are a number of the proponents of the Australia Card legislation, that we all have driving licences and credit cards and this will just be another card. I do not agree with that argument and it needs to be explained. If we have a driving licence it is because we wish to drive a car, and we get a licence from the Government to do that. That is, we have an agreement between the Government and the individual to have a licence to do the thing on the licence-drive a motor vehicle. That is a one-off operation and the information that the individual puts in to get that licence should not be available to any other part of government for any other reason. It should be limited and quarantined to the driving licence itself.

The issue of credit cards is a matter of choice by individuals who wish to have those cards available to them to carry out financial and commercial transactions. I recognise that it is a limited choice in many ways because if one wants to live in a modern society, one has to have credit cards. However, it is again a matter of choice, and responsibility ought to go with the bank or the commercial organisation concerned with which one has the credit card arrangement to protect one's privacy in relation to the information that one reveals in one's application for that card and in the transactions that one carries out by virtue of the use of that card.

The honourable member for Chifley challenged Opposition members to express concern. I respond to that challenge and express concern. I think that there is a need for privacy legislation in relation to the state of affairs that exists at the present time. There is a need for privacy legislation in relation to private databanks that hold information about individuals. There is a need for privacy legislation in relation to information available from banks and credit card organisations, so that the use to which they can put the information that they hold and have is restricted, and in relation to whether they can trade lists and give them to other commercial organisations.

I understand that the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) is currently writing to certain bank account holders offering them free life insurance, or life insurance-I am not sure whether it is free or otherwise, but that is not relevant to the point. The point is that here is a bank writing to individual customers. I would be interested to know on what basis it does so. On the form that one has to fill in for the life insurance is a whole range of personal details. It raises real questions of privacy of the individual, and there is a need today for transactions of that type to be protected by privacy legislation so that the bank, in this case the ANZ, with personal data about us keeps it private. Banks have personal details of the lives of each and every one of us because we fill in application forms for loans and so on. There is a need for strict controls on the use that that information can be put to because we have no common law right, as individuals, to query the banks' use of that information other than for fraud-and I am not suggesting that. There is a need for the privacy of each of us to be protected.

This legislation is part of the Australia Card double. The so-called privacy legislation goes hand in hand with the Australia Card Bill. The Government is not interested in privacy as a matter of principle because it has had a report from the Law Reform Commission since 1983. The Government has only suddenly discovered privacy as an issue and now professes concern about it because of the ID card legislation. The Government is attempting to make that legislation look respectable by bringing to the House the Privacy Bill that we are debating today. The Government is not interested in privacy; it is just a pretence to say to the community, `We are concerned because we have presented this privacy legislation'.

Australia needs an adequate scheme for the protection of privacy-there is a crying need for it-but not the weak effort that is embodied in this pretence of legislation, a pretence that the Government is concerned with privacy when it is doing away with it in one massive step with this Australia Card legislation. It is an abortive attempt to profess concern as it introduces the most iniquitous legislation to control the lives of individual Australians that has ever been introduced. The privacy legislation is a charade; it is a patch-up job. The Government has done nothing. It has sat on the Law Reform Commission report since it received it in 1983. This is an outrage.

One of the greatest problems for government and democracy today is the growth of the bureaucracy; it is one of the great dangers in our society. The growth of bureaucracy is problem enough but, coupled with the new information technology that is available through computers and databases and the linking of those databases through computers, it becomes frightening. It adds exponentially to the power of bureaucracy and, as a corollary, the growth of bureaucracy. Through the wonderful developments of new technology bureaucrats are being given an exponential increase in their power over our lives to an extent that they have never had before.

The growth of bureaucracy is frightening enough without the advent of modern technology. With it, this growth becomes exponentially more frightening and the need to do something about it and to have effective privacy legislation-not the charade that just been produced to the House-becomes even greater. The information on computer databases is horrendous. It provides greater power than the Government has ever had before over the lives of Australians. In practice, it gives bureaucrats more power, because of the information they have, over the lives of Australians in an implied way than governments had in practice in real power when Australians had identity cards in Word War II.

TALK.START.PARA: —More power than in any other Western democracy.
—As the honourable member quite rightly interjects, that is more power over citizens than in any other Western democracy.
—That is just not true.

—It is true, and the honourable member for Prospect alarms me because he is a man on the Government side that I have respect for. I would have thought he would be one person not to trust any bureaucrat with the type of information that is available under this Australia Card legislation. SPEECH.PARA: Not so. Never so. A government is a temporary instrument of power.
That power is vested permanently in an entrenched public service. The public service can be brought to account for its action only with the greatest difficulty.

All men are corruptible, all power corrupts in greater or less degree. In a democracy the only safe course is to cede to our elected servants as little power as is necessary and to call them constantly to answer for their use of it.

I add to what Morris West said. People have to get behind the elected representatives because our power-as members of this House-to get to the bureaucracy is limited. The greatest threat is the bureaucracy that lies behind the Executive government of this nation. It is the bureaucracy that will be given greater power by the Australia Card legislation, and that legislation gives more power over individuals. This power of the bureaucracy is frightening. There is a need to limit it. Freedom has never been more under threat and attack than it is in Australia at present. Undoubtedly there is a need for privacy legislation to restore that balance and freedom before legislation is introduced that further takes privacy away in the massive way that occurs in the Australia Card legislation. The Law Council of Australia, which represents 23,000 barristers and solicitors, says that the legislation provides inadequate protection of privacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do the Labor lawyers say?

—State Labor governments will desert this legislation the nearer they get to their elections because they know that Australians abhore legislation of this nature and resist authoritarianism in every form. There is a campaign in my electorate. People are flooding my office with petitions. In the mall in Melbourne I was part of a group of Liberals campaigning against this legislation and people were queuing up to sign petitions to present to this House against the ID card. That is how much the card is hated by the electorate. I call on the Government to withdraw it.

SPEECH.PARA: I get back to the Data Protection Agency, the so-called protector under this legislation of our privacy. This will create just another bureaucracy with control over our lives. I would like to deal with some comments in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who introduced this legislation, but I am cognisant that my time is running out so I will just say that the Minister, when introducing this legislation, said:
Commonwealth agencies must have a lawful purpose for collecting personal information, and the purpose must be related to the functions or activities of the collector:
He went on to say that personal information, which is part of the information that can be collected:
is widely defined to include anything-fact, true or false, or opinion-that reasonably identifies the information-subject.

The bureaucracy will triumph again and honourable members will find that the rights of individual Australians are condemned and damned in practice. I urge the House to vote against the legislation.

Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for giving me the time to speak on this matter. I tender my concern on this matter. Over 50 to 60 people daily ring my office. TALK.START.PARA: —The first clause of the Privacy Bill is the short title, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act may be cited as the Privacy Act 1986.

This legislation is a classic example of the Hawke Government's two-card trick-it is taking away privacy, it is invading privacy, with its identity card legislation, and with this Bill, to be known as the Privacy Act, it is pretending to protect some of our rights to privacy. There is no doubt that over time there has been an increasing tendency with all government regulation and control towards the invasion of individual privacy, and there is a need to ensure the protection of individual privacy. But this Bill does not do that, and indeed it has been introduced only because the Government is introducing the ID card legislation which, as I have said, is one of the most gross invasions of privacy that this country has ever seen.

As I have said, the short title explains that this legislation will become the Privacy Act. I want to draw the Committee's attention to concerns that I and a number of others on this side of the chamber have with the legislation. The Government, in clauses 1 to 5, clause 6 and a number of other clauses, refers to the ID card legislation and the establishment of the Data Protection Agency. Supposedly the Data Protection Agency will assist in the protection of individual privacy and maintain the confidentiality of information which will be stored as a result of the implementation of the ID card system. The concern I want to raise relates not just to the information stored on the Australia Card Register itself, but to other information stored by departments which is currently held by separate departments in files, more often than not document files, rather than computer files, without there being a unique identifier which links all those files. But under the ID card legislation we will for the first time have a register. People will have to provide certain information in order to get their ID card and that information will be recorded on the register. Once people have their number, they will become known as a 12-digit number and so, over time, people will be identified by that number on all the other files held by government departments including the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Community Services and Health. These files will be identified by this same unique identifier, a person's ID card number.

As I have said, to this date I suppose my file in the Taxation Office is filed under my name or perhaps my tax file number, so someone wanting to get information on my income tax return would have to know my name or my tax file number and then would have to get into the Tax Office and get access to that physical file. As I understand it, the files are not sufficiently computerised yet to have all that information on computer. So it is a physical task to get in there or get someone from the Office to get the information. The concern I express is that once we have the ID card, the unique identifier, it will not be necessary for someone actually to get into the Tax Office and get the information he might want on me which is now held by just that Office. Rather, with the unique identifier, once we have the number we will have access, as these departments go on computer, to all the records that are held about individual citizens-their health records, income tax records, and social security records; and, no doubt, as other departments go on computer and use the ID card number, foreign affairs records, immigration records and so on will all be linked with this one number.

The Government says, `But that is not right. This Privacy Bill, the Data Protection Agency and other security measures taken by the Government will ensure that people will not be able to get access to your information. We will set up all these protective measures to ensure that people cannot readily get access to your information. For example, we will limit the number of people who have access to the computer which will access the ID card register, which is the first step to getting the other information held in departments such as Health, or the Australian Taxation Office, using your ID card number. So we will limit the number of people who have access to the ID card register'. The Government also says that those who access that register will be identified by the computer and that that identification will be recorded. So if a clerk named Joe Smith accesses the register, it will actually be recorded by the computer that Smith has accessed the register. The Government says that that is protection for the individual.

I put it to the Committee that that provides very little protection. There will be terminals all round the country. Once a person has access to the register, what happens to the information that comes out from the register? Is it converted into a written document? If it is, if it becomes a document of some form, what protection is there in relation to the document? That can be used in any way an individual likes. Despite all these complicated devices to ensure that only a limited number of people have access to the register and that, when they have access, they are identified, once the information is actually converted to a document what security is there in relation to that piece of paper? Of course, that piece of paper can be leaked and so on. In addition, what guarantee is there that I will not be able, for example, to use someone else's identification to access the computer? What security will there be in relation to the restricted number of people supposedly who have access to the register? We are not told that.

Another of the concerns is hackers getting into the computer. The Government says, `That will not be able to occur because we will have dedicated landlines'. Even if dedicated landlines work-and there is some doubt that they will-is the Government saying that the Department of Social Security, the Tax Office and the Department of Community Services and Health will all have dedicated landlines? If they do not, once someone knows a person's ID card number and all the files are linked by that unique identifier, the ID card number, the hackers can get into the Social Security, the Tax Office or the Health computers. Once they have the ID card number they have access to the files. So it is not just a matter of having a dedicated landline for ID card purposes for the ID card register. The Government has to give us dedicated landlines for all the departments because once the ID card comes in each person's record in each department will have the one number and that will give access to all information held by the various departments on an individual.

Despite all the guarantees that have been given by the Government and this legislation called the Privacy Bill, my view is that there will be no protection of individual privacy and that the ID card legislation and this legislation together are one of the greatest invasions of privacy that this country has ever seen. The Government's promise to provide protection of individual privacy with this very limited legislation means nothing at all. It really is the classic two-card trick. The Government says, `We will bring in an ID card. We will number you, but we will protect your privacy by introducing this Privacy Bill'-which does absolutely nothing. The concern I expressed a moment ago relates not only to the records now all being linked with a unique identifier but also to the fact that, if other departments' records go on computers, people can hack into all those records and with a person's ID card number access personal information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support strongly the comments made by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). This chamber listened at an earlier stage to a seven-page outline of the legislation presented by the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). We now have a last opportunity at the committee stage to express a response, and that response must take into account some of the pertinent statements made by the Attorney-General. First of all, he told this chamber that at common law there is no enforceable right to privacy as such. However, there are various existing legal rights that protect aspects of what are generally regarded as individual privacy. He admitted that, in recent times, there have been enormous developments in technology for processing information and providing opportunities for building up and using information on individuals. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: This has focused attention on the need to provide more comprehensive measures for protecting privacy against the threat posed by misuse of this technology.
The really significant point is:
This has been recognised during the development of the Australia Card by the decision to establish the Data Protection Agency . . .

All of this significantly draws attention to the fact that, despite this legislation which the Committee is now considering and its relationship to the Australia Card legislation, the real truth of the matter is that privacy is at risk. The real truth of the matter is that, if this legislation is passed, all Australians will find themselves at risk from the point of view of reasonable privacy. What do we find in the information before us that we must take into account? We find that this is really a smokescreen to try to give the impression that there is a legislative process that will create protection. The truth of the matter obviously is that, in the modern day of technology advancement and so on, there can be no guarantee.

The honourable member for Barker sounded a warning in a very appropriate way and I am sure that honourable members on both sides of the chamber will have taken notice of that warning. I urge the Committee at this stage to move to recommit this Bill and the related Australia Card legislation. It creates the risk, the very premise, upon which privacy would be lost. The mere existence of this legislation would be an inadequate protection. I believe that the majority of members of this House, if they were given a free vote, would throw out this legislation. The Bill still has to pass the third reading stage. I hope there will be time before this legislation becomes law-if it is not done now-for it to be reassessed so that the facts can be brought to light. If that were done, there is no question that a vote against it would occur.

On behalf of my constituents, the people who have approached me in recent weeks, those who now realise the dangers, I say very strongly that we on this side of the chamber oppose this Bill with all the vigour and capacity that we have, and we will go on doing so regardless of what occurs during the remainder of the committee stage this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday night, before this debate was interrupted by the adjournment debate, I outlined the magnitude of the amount of additional income tax to be harvested in this financial year and the next. The amount of income tax to be paid by individuals, not by companies, will increase by $2 1/4 billion over the 1987-88 financial year and by $5 billion in the next financial year. Despite the illusory reductions which became effective on 1 July--
—The biggest taxing government of all time.

—Indeed, it has the record and it looks like keeping it for the rest of the time that it remains in office. That is in keeping with the record of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his Government-the biggest taxers in our history, as the honourable member for Berowra has interjected. This Government simply fails to recognise that the disincentive of excessive taxation is reflected in people's willingness to work, save, invest and take economic risks. When tax rates become excessive, as they remain today, people not only do less of these productive activities, but also they move into the underground and barter economies. They smuggle, evade taxes and even vote with their feet by moving to places where the correlation between effort and reward is more advantageous.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, as if to justify an overall increase of 9.2 per cent in the amount of all income tax to be collected in this financial year-an increase, incidentally, which is well in excess of the projected inflation rate of just over 6 per cent-with twisted logic, invokes his new capital gains tax. That ploy in his Budget Speech is of more interest for what it does not say about the capital gains tax than for what it does say. The Department of the Treasury, not the Treasurer, tells us at pages 298 and 299 of Budget Paper No. 1 that capital gains taxes will yield $50m to $100m in this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was going to be five.

—Yes, it was going to be five. But that is not a bad margin for error-$50m to $100m. The difficulty is probably explained at length, if not all that convincingly I suppose, in footnote (d). Although $50m to $100m is not all that significant-except for us mere mortals-for a Budget which sets out to spend a total of more than $78 billion, comparatively insignificantly as it is, the Treasurer can use expected new capital gains raisings to justify a return to negative gearing for certain income producing property. That thinking, however juvenile and unworthy of one who would be Prime Minister one day, is better than having to admit that the coalition's warnings, given at the time, about the consequential effects of the self-same Treasurer's earlier outlawing of negative gearing benefits for property owners and those providing rental income, were correct. The Treasurer, who is not one to eat humble pie or admit his mistakes, has avoided acknowledging his earlier stupidity in this connection.

SPEECH.PARA: His Department is more circumspect, however, particularly about the total amount of capital gains tax to be gained in this financial year. In the Budget Papers the Treasury makes it clear that the new capital gains tax was not a factor worth mentioning when talking about collections in excess of estimates for the financial year 1986-87, that is, last year. While Government members at large have sought to show otherwise, vast additional amounts have been raised under the section 26aaa provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act-not the capital gains tax provision-which were in place long before the present Government came to office in 1983. So-called tax reform cannot therefore be accurately cited, as some honourable members opposite would have us believe. Because share trading has boomed over the past 12 months or so, section 26aaa collections exceeded estimates for last year, and there is a chance that they will exceed estimates this year. With that boom comes a problem for the Government which will mature sooner or later. Everyone knows, or should know, that the bears will have their day in the share market and that every share trading boom is followed by a bust. We all know that it must happen, but few of us are bold enough to say when it will happen. However, when the inevitable occurs, its effects will not only see traders with burnt fingers, but also the Government's coffers will suffer.

With that certain knowledge in mind, the Australian Taxation Office is already establishing the foundation for avoidance practices of its own. Because time will not permit today, I do not intend to go into that matter in detail. I shall certainly take up that issue at an appropriate time.

So much for the claim of tax fairness which the Treasurer made in his speech. Given the wording of the capital gains tax law as it stands now, some measures of fairness in this context would be restored if section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act were repealed with immediate effect. It is no longer relevant. It would have the desirable effect of removing more discretion from the Commissioner of Taxation which he may-I emphasise the word `may'-be tempted to use or abuse, as he has in some of his other areas of discretion.

Many of our economic problems appear to have only belatedly registered with the Government. Although the portents have been there for all to see for some two or three years, the big spending, big taxing and big borrowing policies of the earlier Hawke-Keating governments laid the foundation for the great difficulties we have at the moment. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) alone in the Government seems to have grasped the gravity of our economic problems. He alone in the Government is credible in identifying the frightening prospects and advocating possible remedies. Senator Walsh seems to understand that economic growth is a process of individual self-generated increase in expansion. It is not a process of collecting drops from some great bucket of wealth in the sky. While his remarks at the weekend are topical and even though he may not, as the Treasurer now claims, have brought his views before the Cabinet, the truth is that this senior Cabinet Minister has been unable to convince the Government of the folly of its Budget.

The speech made by Senator Walsh at the weekend was not, after all, his first in the same vein. On 7 August this year, before the Budget was finalised, he spoke in a similar way. An interesting side issue which says much about the lack of cohesion in the inner sanctums of this Government is that its Minister for Finance had to take his arguments on two occasions to the public, as it were, to state a case which his peers did not want a bar of. I think that that is a measure of the lack of fiscal competence of this Government and there is no better person than Senator Walsh to have made that point apparent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88, I am pleased to support a national Budget of which Australians should be proud. This is not only because of the reduction in the deficit, important though that may be: the importance is for the long term well-being of Australians as the detrimental effects of governments going beyond their means to provide essential services are virtually obliterated with the presentation of Australia's first balanced Budget for some years. Honourable members will remember that when we came to office in 1983 the Department of the Treasury projected a deficit blowout of $9 billion to $10 billion. In the 1986-87 Budget brought down by this Government the deficit had been dragged back to $2.7 billion. Now, at the start of the Thirty-fifth Parliament, with the Australian Labor Party's historic third consecutive victory, and in Lilley our historic fourth consecutive victory, the Hawke Government has brought down a widely acclaimed Budget-Australia's first virtually balanced Budget since 1970-71. The domestic deficit with which we have lived and on which we, the taxpayers, have paid interest is now $27m in the context of a $78,146m Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Indicators show that the Labor Government's policies to lift our economic performance, bringing down interest rates and inflation and increasing job opportunities are working. The first indicators are there and there is room for much encouragement. In fact, this should encourage all sectors of our society as neither the most creative nor the most reformist of policies will benefit working people and those without jobs if the country is allowed to lurch into depression. But encouraging as the balanced Budget is, it would have been unsatisfactory if it had been achieved at the cost of low income and disadvantaged people in our society.
