TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The importance of this measure should not be talked down. Although it will not benefit all Australians in the short term in that those with two children and earning $430 or more a week and those with three children and earning $500 or more a week, phasing out to a family with five children and earning $600, will not gain from the package, it will benefit the nation by lifting our ethical standards as a nation. Poverty should not be allowed even to exist in Australia. According to today's Courier-Mail, Mr Julian Disney, the President of the Australian Council of Social Service, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the number of Australians living in poverty had increased substantially over the past 10 years to more than 2 million.
That is entirely unacceptable. Mr Disney also said:
. . . new initiatives by the Government, including the Family Assistance Package, would have a significant impact on the incidence of poverty.
While poverty was on the increase, the Australian nation had become substantially richer.

The problem is that the gap between those who are substantially richer and those who are substantially poorer was widened. As Mr Disney says, more resources must be allocated in the future to relieve this poverty in a number of positive ways. This Budget is a very good start. I am pleased that the general public supports it as this support will enable the Government to make the family package the first of a number of similar packages. But to do this, we must recoup money lost to Australia through methodical and dishonest abuse of the tax and welfare systems by some people. That is why we should support the Australia Card. Certainly, there are questions of privacy which are being well canvassed. Those questions have been there for at least a decade, as the business world has reaped the advantages of sophisticated computer systems. Where were all the crusaders of civil liberties in the Opposition then?

Members of the public have been subjected to having their names, addresses, credit ratings, taste in reading matter, art, household furnishings or heaven knows what else recorded on lists which have been offered at a price to a variety of direct marketing organisations. Evidently it was all right to turn a blind eye to the sale of people's rights of privacy to benefit certain business people but suddenly it is not all right to use the same technology of computerisation to benefit taxpayers who are being ripped off because some people effectively protected by the old system will not pay their way. These are the same honest, taxpaying, average Australians whose jobs were put at risk while machines took over from men and women. Only the unions protested loudly on behalf of those workers at risk. Now it is proposed that the system be used to benefit those self-same people, and lobbies have emerged to kill the proposal at its inception.

I am particularly angered by the distortions used to discredit the Australia Card proposal by people who should and do know better. I refer particularly to the references made to the nazi system under Adolf Hitler which used a pass system. To suggest that because such an oppressive and horrific regime used a pass system, or any system, to attack its own people, and that such a card system would do the same in a democracy such as Australia, is ludicrous. It is tantamount to saying that because Adolf Hitler used the army against the people to oppress them, we should do away with the army in Australia. If we have a future oppressive government, we, as a people, are in big trouble. It would use our entire communications system, our defence forces and our transport outlets against the people. Do we do away with those services because it is quite okay to use them under a good government but they may be used against us under another government? The Australian editorial commented on 8 May 1985:

The average Australian today has a Medicare card, a Bankcard and probably one or more other credit cards issued by department stores, credit unions or organisations such as American Express or Diners Club. The Australian Taxation Office has a record of his income and tax-deductible expenditure, and the Immigration Department knows if he has a passport and has travelled overseas. The Electoral Office has a record of his address and occupation, and his State government knows if he has a drivers licence and owns a car.

There has been a breakthrough in that the Data Protection Agency is now proposed as part of this legislation. This should be welcomed and worked upon. I do not intend to canvass all of the issues again.

I have for people in my electorate and other people in that area a listing of the workings of the Australia Card. That will be available upon request. I do not suggest that serious reservations regarding privacy expressed by concerned and thoughtful people should be brushed aside, but surely the rewards for the large majority of law-abiding Australians are worth a little more constructive suggestion regarding ways to amend the legislation as suggested by Senator Ryan rather than tossing out a major means of bringing in the revenue needed to implement important social reforms such as the family package to narrow the gap between those Australians who have adequate or excess financial support and those who, to our joint shame, have not.

I have received many expressions of support for and of protest against the Australia Card. I am taking note of all these viewpoints. But overall I am saying, `Give the proposal a go. Make it work. Give it your very best effort'. The poor just cannot wait any longer on the sidelines for the resolution of a public debate which is really based not on this particular card, but on privacy provisions for all computerised systems which have been operative in Australia for years. I am saying, `Continue with the debate by all means and provide additional privacy provisions to cover the systems already in use including the Australia Card, but do not cut the life support system of the poor'.

There are a number of anomalies or social injustices which have caused great stress for certain groupings of people. I am pleased to report that this Budget has addressed these. One such anomaly is an aspect I addressed to Senator Ryan following the introduction of Austudy this year. This is an interim payment before Austudy is granted. If people on unemployment benefit advise the Department of Social Security that they are undertaking full time study they lose eligibility to employment benefit and may apply for Austudy. At present, unemployment benefit is cancelled immediately the Department receives verification that Austudy will be paid. However, there is usually a gap between the time benefit is cancelled and Austudy commences. This most certainly caused stress to a number of people who were on unemployment benefit and had that benefit cut off, including the rent allowance, and who then had to wait until their Austudy payments came in. Therefore, I am very pleased that before 1 January 1988 benefit will continue to be paid until the study course starts. Austudy, when granted, is paid from 1 January and any excess benefit paid for the same period will be recovered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

Another change which will be welcomed by the Australian people is to the child disability allowance. The child disability allowance will be introduced from 15 November 1987 and will replace the existing handicapped child's allowance. The handicapped child's allowance is paid under two categories: severely disabled, which is income test free, and substantially disabled, which is subject to a financial hardship test. This has concerned me and others and we have expressed this concern. The child disability allowance, I am pleased to say, will make no distinction between severely and substantially disabled children. This is very welcome. It will be paid income test free to all disabled children covered under the current category of handicapped child's allowance. The child disability allowance will be $112 a month-an increase of $20 over the handicapped child's allowance currently paid at a maximum rate of $92 a month.

I also welcome the extension of eligibility to the much used and very welcome carer's pension. The carer's pension is presently available to near relatives who provide constant care and attention to an age or invalid pensioner. From 1 February 1988 eligibility for this pension will be extended to people who are not close relatives but who are providing constant care and attention to severely physically or mentally disabled age or invalid pensioners living in the same home. This will provide much needed financial support for those people who have already dedicated much of their lives to the care of others in extreme need. I welcome this aspect of the Budget.

Another point is the retention of fringe benefits. At present, fringe benefit entitlements cease once gross weekly income reaches $75 for a single person, $126 combined for a couple, plus $20 for each dependent child-student in their care. From 1 January 1988, people will be able to retain entitlement to fringe benefits for up to three months if their income rises by no more than 25 per cent above the fringe benefit allowable income levels. For example, a single person whose gross weekly income does not exceed $95.75-that is 125 per cent of the $75 allowable income level-will be able to retain fringe benefit eligibility for up to three months. If the income does not drop below the fringe benefit allowable income limit within that three-month period, eligibility will then cease. So again, compassionately, time is given to people who are suddenly caught in this situation.

In regard to sole parents retaining fringe benefits, in the May economic statement, the maximum eligibility for widow's pension Class A and supporting parent's benefit was restricted to people with a dependent child under the age of 16 years. This meant that a number of sole parents whose only dependent child was a student aged 16 to 24 would lose their entitlement from 1 September 1987. This has caused much concern. To give these people more time to adjust their plans for the future, sole parents who lose their pension or benefit between 1 September and 31 December 1987 as a result of that change, will retain their eligibility to fringe benefits until the end of 1988 provided, apart from the age of the qualifying child, they remain eligible for fringe benefits.

In this context I am also representing a number of people in my electorate, women who have given their time to stay home and look after their families for many years, particularly those who married at a time when it was not expected, and there were no provisions, for people to be able to find extra work outside the home. As a result of being with their families for many years they now find that they lack the confidence to be able to emerge from this situation and to be able to take on paid outside work where there is paid outside work available. Therefore, I will be speaking with the appropriate committees and with the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) regarding the situation which these people are facing.

Sole parents currently in full time Austudy approved courses before 1 September 1987 who would have lost pension or benefit after 1 September 1987 because the youngest student child is over 16 years of age will now be able to continue receiving payment until they complete their courses of study provided they meet the other eligibility requirements. These people will also continue to be paid an education allowance from the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

There are many aspects of this Budget to which I would like to address myself, but time does not permit at this stage. However, I would like to repeat that a Budget has been brought in which acknowledges that a large number of people within Australia have been having a terrible struggle bringing up families when their pay packets, pension envelopes or cheques have not been enough to go round on a week by week basis. They have not been enough for some people to be able to clothe or feed their children properly. In any nation, this is entirely unacceptable, but this is especially so in a comparatively affluent nation such as Australia, regardless of the problems we are facing. I am very pleased that the Government has taken a stand in moving to offer more than kind words to people who are caught in this dreadful poverty trap. It is about time that this nation showed that it is indeed a mature, grown-up nation willing to accept responsibility for those people who are in an under-privileged situation. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling). It is about time that we showed that we are a mature and responsible nation, and recognised the severe economic plight in which we find ourselves. I repeat my comment that it is a great pity that the Government does not take it upon itself to replace the incumbent Treasurer (Mr Keating) with the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. It is a great pity that we are not debating Senator Walsh's Budget, because he at least is publicly prepared to discuss the real issues that face Australia today. I am afraid that I have to agree with him and disagree fundamentally with the Treasurer in his approach to preparing the Budget this year.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of those honourable members who have not heard Senator Walsh's comments, let me make some brief reference to his remarks, which were made in Perth during the weekend. He said that the Budget may have been `oversold'. That may be an understatement because Treasurer Keating's Budgets are a multimedia spectacular rather than a statement of economic policy. We even changed the sitting time of the House to accommodate the needs of the television networks. He makes sure that there is dramatic impact, and very little detail. Unfortunately, that does no service to the Australian economy.
At the weekend, Senator Walsh not only made that point, but said that there was complacency in the Government about its economic management. He is also reported as saying:
There are 200 government-funded programs that cannot be justified on social or equity grounds;
The Federal Government lacked the necessary political courage to bite into indulgent social welfare programs;

I find that comment most telling when it was not so long ago that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was telling the entire nation that we were in a crisis akin to a war and that it was absolutely necessary that we all recognise that and take the hard decisions. In the election campaign, and even during recent weeks, the Prime Minister has been running around the country saying, `My Government has taken the hard decisions. We have addressed the issues that needed to be addressed'. He is creating the impression that the Government has solved Australia's economic problems and adjusted the structure of the Australian economy to accommodate the changing world circumstances, so we no longer have anything to worry about. That was the general impression pervading the Treasurer's presentation in the chamber the other night.

However, we find that a member of the Cabinet, and of the Government Expenditure Review Committee, the Minister for Finance, whose name is jointly on all the Budget Papers with that of the Treasurer, is saying, `This is not true. The Government lacks guts. It is cowardly. It is not prepared to get on with the job of taking the tough decisions in Australia and putting our country back on the right track'. The problem that we have is that the Treasurer has, in recent weeks, admitted his desire to become Prime Minister. The Treasurer is also an astute politician, and he knows that Treasurers in this country have a bad image in the public because generally they are delivering bad news, putting up the price of cigarettes and beer, increasing taxes-taking all those tough decisions about which people get upset. If one aspires to be Prime Minister, one has to have a very good approval rating and be popular. One does not want to be tagged as being the Treasurer, the chap who took all those nasty decisions which make people dislike him. If one has a choice between the Walsh option, which is the sensible option that addresses the fiscal realities of Australia today and of our place in a rapidly changing and competitive world and the option taken by the Treasurer the other night and one aspires to be Prime Minister, I guess one has the preference of going for the soft option, which is a disaster for Australia.

I shall deal with that at length later. First, I would like to discuss the media reaction to the Budget. The Treasurer walked in here on Tuesday night and his calculated speech began with these words:
Madam Speaker, the Budget for 1987-88 is in balance.
The deficit has been cut to . . . $27m.

That is all that we heard of, that is all that the Press Gallery reported, and that was on the television or in the newspapers the next morning. There was very little critical analysis of the Budget and its implications for Australia in its current economic circumstances. I find such a euphoric response amazing when the economic reality of Australia today is fairly bad. Australia still has, as I said earlier today, a foreign debt of about $110 billion, and it is rising. We have a current account deficit in excess of $11 billion, and despite the sometimes glib statements of the Treasurer and other members of the Government, it is not likely to go away in two or three years.

We still have 9 per cent inflation, which is very high, particularly when compared with rates of inflation in the United States of America and western Europe. We still have 8.5 per cent unemployment and, interestingly, this Government, in its Budget, says that nothing much will happen with unemployment. It has traded off the spectacular image overseas, the glib presentation of the Budget, for unemployment. It does not anticipate that growth and job creation in the economy will do anything about the 8.5 per cent unemployment rate. Fundamentally, we still have the lowest rate of private investment in productive capital for almost two decades.

It concerns me greatly that this is the Government's attitude, and that it is quite hypocritical in its approach. We have heard ad nauseam from Government members about the hundreds of thousands of jobs that have been created by the Hawke Labor Government. I have never heard so much rubbish in my life. The Hawke Labor Government has created only those jobs on which it has spent taxpayers' money creating spots in the public sector, for a short time in most cases. The reality is that in the Australian economy, the private sector creates jobs, not the Government. People who are prepared to invest their capital and risk their savings to establish a business and employ other people create jobs. Governments do not create jobs, and it astounds me that the glib reporting of the Gallery keeps talking about government-created jobs. If the Gallery wants to confine its remarks exclusively to public sector jobs, technically it is correct, but in terms of private sector jobs, it is nothing short of economic rubbish to talk about the government-created jobs. Someone should take some sections of the media through an analysis of what the economy will do in terms of job creation at a normal rate, and compare that with what has happened over the past few years under the Hawke Labor Government.

Senator Walsh understands exactly what the Treasurer has done with his Budget. He has walked away from fiscal responsibility and put down a Budget which is predicated on continuing high rates of foreign capital inflow to Australia. That foreign capital inflow goes into the public and private sectors by way of borrowing, foreign equity investment and foreign portfolio investment-equity into Australian businesses, portfolio investment through our stock exchanges-and investment in real estate. It is this capital inflow that is enabling the current Government's policies to continue, because it will finance our current account deficit. This foreign capital inflow has been attracted by our low dollar and our high interest rates, with the result that the dollar has been pushed up.

When the dollar was allowed to float and it fell, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister said, `We have to have a dollar which reflects the real value of the Australian currency, and, by the way, it will restore international competitiveness to Australian industry'. But rather than have a free float of the dollar and allow it to move to reflect the true value, the Government has had the Reserve Bank of Australia involved in the market. These days the exchange rate really is managed. The Reserve Bank has been able to make considerable profits as a result of trading in the Australian dollar. Notwithstanding that, the inflow of capital has pushed up the value of the Australian dollar and reduced that competitive advantage that Australian industry was getting from the reduced dollar.

Foreign capital has also been attracted to our country by our very high rates of interest. We have had record high interest rates for almost the entire term of this Government. They are slipping now, but I will return to that in a few moments. Those high rates of interest were deliberate because this Government would not come to grips with wages policy and with fiscal restraint and also needed foreign capital inflow. If the dollar is undervalued or low and there are high rates of interest, money will be moved internationally into this country and will finance the activities of a government if it is not prepared to take those hard decisions and come to grips with them. This foreign capital inflow has not only pushed up the value of the dollar but has also fuelled the stock exchange boom. There is an immense amount of foreign capital in the Australian Stock Exchange at present and in our capital markets generally.

I have mentioned that the Reserve Bank's activity in terms of trading in the Australian dollar as the result of capital inflow and the floating of the dollar has contributed to this Budget of well over $1 billion. Also, foreign capital in our stock exchanges has contributed to balancing this Budget. Capital gains tax on shares has reaped an unexpected harvest and as a result has made a substantial contribution to balancing the Budget. This Government, despite its rhetoric about tax cuts, is planning a 9 per cent increase in income tax receipts this fiscal year. That is partly the result of the inflation occurring through the Government's monetary and fiscal policies and its failure to come to grips with a decentralised wages policy.

It is interesting to note that in the past five years, the Hawke Labor Government's income has increased by 75 per cent. People express amazement at how the Treasurer managed to balance the Budget. But he did not balance the Budget the real way, the tough way, by coming to grips with waste. He did it by taxing Australians and Australian businesses more and more.

TALK.START.PARA: —If he balanced it at all.

—The honourable member for Farrer questions whether he balanced it at all. He is alluding to the two points that have been discussed before; that is, that the Budget has been balanced only by selling off part of Australia's national assets and by taking into account those exchange trading profits of the Reserve Bank. It is interesting to note that, if the standards of the corporate sector were applied to this Budget, the Treasurer would not be allowed to do that. Unless one is a currency speculator-and I hope the Australian Government is not a professional currency speculator-exchange gains are an extraordinary item and should appear below the line. That is the reality. It is a source of income that cannot be guaranteed for the next year. If the Treasurer were being economically responsible he certainly would not have included that in the Budget this year. Perhaps more should have been made of that in reporting the Budget and its impact on our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer's Budget rests, as I said, on continuing capital inflow, borrowing more and selling more-borrowing more to finance the Government's expenditure and the activities of the private sector, and selling more of Australian equity; either selling government-owned assets, assets owned by the Australian people, or selling an equity position in Australian businesses and allowing foreign investors into our real estate market. Heaven only knows, we have seen the impact of that recently, particularly in Sydney, with an escalation of prices. We have also seen foreign investors take very strong positions in Australian stock exchanges and capital markets.

The problem we face with this approach to the Budget is that the Budget is very much like a house of cards. If the foreign capital inflow, for one reason or another, stops, so does everything else. It is based on confidence and is fairly much of a gamble. We have seen interest rates fall in recent months. Part of the attraction for foreign capital to come into Australia is our above average interest rates. If our interest rates continue to fall, particularly in the context of overseas interest rates rising-and that is the situation that pertains in the United States at the present time-there will come a point when the attractiveness of investing in Australia and transferring international capital into the Australian economy will be reduced substantially. When that point is reached, either capital inflow ceases or our interest rates have to go back up again.

The other consequence of continuing capital inflow is that the value of the Australian dollar continues to go up. In recent days it has hit 73c, which is a considerably higher level than the 57c that I remember something less than two years ago. The two reactions will have a dramatic impact on how this Government can continue to handle Australia's economy and on what that means for Australians generally and Australian business. If interest rates are forced to rise again, there will be more and more pressure on the profitability of the business sector. If our dollar is pushed up as a result of this capital inflow, the competitiveness of our industries will be reduced and the much vaunted J-curve certainly will not work at all. As one of my colleagues said the other day, it will turn into a walking stick and be very much of a crutch for the Treasurer.

As Senator Walsh said in Perth, the problem is that we are not coming to grips with the real problems of the Australian economy. They will not be addressed until we show fiscal responsibility and restraint. There is an overwhelming need in this economy to reduce government expenditure. If Senator Walsh can, off the top of his head, name 200 government programs which cannot be justified in economic or social terms, a thorough and ongoing review of government expenditure would come up with considerably more. The savings available would be sufficient to genuinely provide Australia with a balanced Budget. Of course, what is also necessary is a reduction in tax. It is necessary to consider only two things-the 9 per cent projected increase in income tax revenues for the coming financial year and the 75 per cent increase in total Federal government revenues over five years-to see exactly what has gone on in the course of this Government.

The Government has balanced the Budget not by reducing expenditure but by increasing taxes. The one thing that our economy should not be burdened with at the present time is a continued increase in tax levies. That reduces incentive. That is why we have perhaps one of the lowest levels of private capital formation in the past 20 years. The prescription for stopping Australia going down the track that we are on at present of a further and continuing decline in living standards and reversing that and moving back into a situation where our economy grows, our productivity increases and people can look forward to rising standards of living in the future is to encourage investment and to provide incentive for people to invest and to work harder. Of course, that means we must reduce tax rates. Unfortunately, to do that would make the Treasurer come to grips with some very tough decisions. Those tough decisions, as I mentioned earlier, might have some impact on his political popularity.

It was said not so many years ago that Treasurer Keating was a determined man. SPEECH.PARA: I want to address later the question of national debt and the balance of payments problem facing Australia.
