Let me quote from Budget Paper No. 1 which refers to the balance of payments in the current year. It states:

Mainly because of continuing, albeit slowing, accumulation of net external debt, the deficit on net property income will increase substantially, thereby continuing to constrain the rate of reduction of the current account deficit.

In other words, to put it in more simple terms, because of the growth in debt and the interest on debt the ability to wind back the deficit on the balance of payments is constrained, to use the Treasurer's own words. Budget Paper No. 1 continues:
These forecasts imply a current account deficit of around $11 1/2 billion-
in the current year-

some 4 per cent of GDP, in 1987-88. Seasonal influences, as usual, are expected to be adverse in the first half . . . Australia's net external debt is likely to continue to rise faster than nominal GDP during 1987-88, and a further rise in the debt servicing ratio is expected.

That is the Treasury's forecast on the balance of payments in the current year. It is little wonder that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-even if he speaks to Labor lawyers only in private-is concerned about the future. The Government, in its own Budget Papers, is saying quite clearly what we should expect in the current year in relation to the balance of payments. We should expect a continuing growth in the balance of payments deficit, a continuing growth in interest payments, paid for by the taxpayers, and an overhang for the whole of Australia. I turn now to a publication by the Committee for Economic Development of Australia (CEDA), which states:
Australia has one of the largest debts in the world . . . Further if we take the EPAC peak estimates-
EPAC is the Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council-

of Australia's net-external-debt-to-GDP ratio . . . it is clear that Australia is about to join a group of either highly borrowed developing countries or industrial countries with severely strained economies.

That was the CEDA response to the comment made by EPAC. Put simply, Australia's net external borrowings are the cumulative result of our current account deficits over many years. These deficits have been made good through overseas fund raisings to the extent that Australian exports of goods and services, plus income from other transfer payments, have not been sufficient to pay for imports of goods and services and income and transfer payments. That part of overseas raisings not covered by equity and property sales has been funded by issuing debt.

The most fundamental explanation of why Australia has a current account deficit is that, as a nation, we have been spending in excess of our income or, what amounts to the same thing, aggregate national savings have been inadequate compared with aggregate national investment. The current account deficit, therefore, is the spill-over result of this excessive spending over inadequate savings and that pattern continues today. An important reason for the rapid expansion of Australia's foreign debt levels has been not only the generally reduced fund raising but also the dramatic fall-off in capital inflow in non-debt forms-equity and property purchases.

Apart from the general worldwide rise in debt-to-equity ratios there are two significant Australian reasons for the trend towards foreign investment in the form of debt rather than equity. Firstly, the actions of the Foreign Investment Review Board, before recent changes, made foreign debt investment in Australia difficult over a large number of years. As a result, debt was the way required capital could flow into Australia. That has been evident in the large purchase of government securities in the years 1983, 1984, 1985, and 1986. It is only very recently that there has been a change in those circumstances. Secondly, the increased reliance on debt is surely a potent illustration of the loss of confidence in the Australian economy by foreign investors. They have voted with their feet in terms of the way in which they have placed Australian money into government securities rather than into equities. This has also occurred in recent times. The reason for that has been the fall in the exchange rate.

While discussing the causes of Australia's foreign debt, I believe it is important for honourable members to understand that the recent large number of corporate raids and stock market takeovers, often financed overseas through debt raisings, has had little to do with the size of Australia's foreign debt and its rapid growth. The need for capital inflow is determined by the size of the current account deficit, and the actual borrowers are simply filling that need through their individual decisions to fund their financial needs off-shore, whether for takeovers or other reasons.

The current account deficit is increasingly due to interest payments on foreign debt. In fact, this year interest payments will represent over 50 per cent of the current account deficit. Over the past 10 years, interest payments have grown by an average of 19 per cent annually. The bringing down of the current account to the historical average of about 2 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), given the increasing drag of interest on foreign debt, will require a massive swing-around to a large surplus of exports over imports of goods and services. In other words, if 80 per cent of this turnaround were to come from exports, the amount of exports would have to increase by $9 billion, or 22 per cent on their 1986 level. The greater Australia's incapacity to generate the necessary higher export revenue, the larger the fall in imports will have to be-basically by slashing people's spending.

Since 1982, the exchange rate has fallen against the trade-weighted basket of currencies by about 40 per cent. This drop reflects the deterioration of the current account. So long as Australia maintains a current account deficit of about 5 or 6 per cent of GDP, foreign debt will continue to grow strongly and the Australian dollar will remain a weak currency. As a result of the lower exchange rate, export prices have tended to lag behind import prices, offsetting part of the favourable volume effects. What is worse, interest payments on the foreign debt have expanded, not just with the higher debt levels associated with continuing current account deficits, but with the larger amount of Australian dollars required to service the same foreign currency denominated interest payments.

In the medium to longer term, exports may expand and imports contract sufficiently. However, the larger the value of the foreign debt, the more the improvement in the goods and services trade is offset by higher interest payments on the foreign debt. Australia is pretty much in the position now in which, due to this factor, further declines in the exchange rate will have only a limited effect on closing the current account deficit. This clearly indicates that adjustment to the current account deficit must come from areas such as private and government spending, and wages and fiscal policies, not through further exchange rate depreciation.

I turn now, in the few moments remaining to me, to interest rates. There is a need to keep the growth of overall demand suppressed in order to keep down import levels and therefore lower the current account deficit to acceptable levels, while fundamental structural economic change occurs. The Government, faced with this requirement, has a number of choices: it can limit government expenditure and rein back the public sector borrowing requirement; it can intervene in the wage setting process to obtain results consistent with economic capacity to pay; or it can implement a monetary policy that has the simultaneous effect of cutting back on the supply of money and credit and suppressing demand through high interest rates.

The problem in Australia is that the chardonnay sippers are incapable of cutting back on their expenditure and borrowing to the required degree. Because of that, the Government is the captive of the trade union movement. It has usually lacked the desire to change its wages policy. This has left tight monetary policy, with its relatively more acceptable political impact, from the Australian Labor Party's point of view, to bear the burden of adjustment. The consequence has been historically high interest rates.

The living standards of Australians will be hard hit for the foreseeable future as a result of the Government's inability to control the current account deficit and foreign debt at an acceptable level. The annual interest bill for Australia's foreign debt this year will be nearly $8 billion, as I have said before, which is equivalent to wiping about 3 per cent off national income. This cut has been increasing over recent years, and it is expected to continue to rise as the debt level increases at a faster rate than that of national income. If this Government is to tackle the capping of foreign debt relative to GDP, the rate of growth of imports must be kept to a low level. The Government should be careful to ensure that the recent decline in interest rates does not act as a catalyst to increase consumer demand. If this problem eventuates, the Government may once again be pushed to the position of hiking up interest rates. The cut in consumer demand for imports will need to be larger to balance the importation of capital equipment that is necessary for the restructuring of Australian industry.

Australia is suffering from a severe external imbalance that manifests itself in continuing large current account deficits and the high level of foreign indebtedness. On an international comparison, this degree of imbalance is relatively severe. Although the causes of Australia's imbalance are a mixture of international and domestic forces, the solutions will have to be basically domestic. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer unwisely find comfort in blaming the problem on the collapse of our export prices and see economic salvation in their recovery. To base Australia's response, or rather inaction, on this outcome would mean risking a huge build-up in our foreign debt levels to a point where economic recovery would be virtually impossible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I commence by congratulating you on your well-deserved re-election to the position of Speaker.
—I thank the honourable member.

—I share some of the pessimism of the previous Opposition speaker, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), as far as our economic future is concerned. I must admit that most of my pessimism as far as this country is concerned lies more at the geopolitical level. I do not want to go into that tonight. I would like to comment on the reaction to the so-called Australia Card which has developed into little more than an hysterical, illogical outcry from people with very vivid imaginations who struggle to outdo each other in scaremonger tactics and in grim religious and Orwellian phrases.

SPEECH.PARA: I was one of three foundation members of the Council for Civil Liberties in New South Wales. Twenty-five years ago, three of us-the late Mr Justice Sweeney, Professor Ken Buckley and I-started the Council for Civil Liberties. It was one of the Councils for Civil Liberties in Australia which was clearly non-political in any party political sense. I was treasurer and a member of its executive for many years and finally resigned two or three years ago when it decided to support an investigation into the so-called Age tapes, which I considered to be extremely inappropriate for a Council for Civil Liberties to do.

I was a member of the original Caucus committee-not the parliamentary committee, the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card-which looked at the proposal for an identity card. I mention one point which does not seem to have been repeated; at least, I have not heard it repeated. For the year for which we gathered evidence from the Australian Taxation Office, financial institutions in Australia-I think it was probably the 1982-83 year, but it could have been 1983-84-paid $13 billion in interest. Tax returns reported only $6.5 billion. I am not suggesting that the other $6.5 billion concerned so-called tax cheats. Obviously, there are people-kids, elderly people, people with no other income-who never earned the amount necessary to have to make out a tax return. However, I would suggest that a large amount of money is not declared for taxation. Suggestions have been made that similarly many rental payments are never declared. If one totalled up the amount of rent that was paid in Australia and the amount that appeared on tax returns, one would find that the figures were nothing like each other. Financial institutions provide the Taxation Office with print-outs or computer tapes of interest paid. The document says, `Roger Shipton'-his address would not be included-`received $173.50 last year'. The Tax Office can match the amount which a person declares and the amount given by the financial institution in only 16 per cent of cases. I find that extremely depressing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree; they should be able to do more but without the ID card.

—The honourable member suggests that more people should be employed. One of the arguments against the ID card is that we will increase the size of the bureaucracy. I am convinced of two things: firstly, a huge amount of money is not being declared for tax purposes and, secondly, there is a large amount of social security fraud, even though the Department of Social Security, which is always quoted now, has said that fraud amounts to only $20m. It is obvious to us all that the total amount of fraud is much larger. What really concerns me about the debate on the ID card is the hysterical reaction that has come out. It is depressing that in a country which claims to have a reasonably high standard of education people can be aroused by that sort of thing. Mike Steketee, who is not one of my favourite journalists, stated in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald last Friday:

SPEECH.PARA: Susan Ryan realised she had entered the lion's den in Launceston last Tuesday when a speaker at a public meeting said that, in Sweden, 6,000 people had had numbers tattooed on their foreheads by laser.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that Launceston?
—Yes. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Closer to home, she has had to handle claims that, under the Australia Card legislation, babies will have to have their wrists tattooed. Others see dark Biblical portents in the Government's action.
Letters to the Government quote Revelation, Chapter 13-
I have received similar letters, thankfully not from my constituents-

on the evil beast which ``required everyone, great and small, rich and poor, slave and free, to be tattooed with a certain mark on the right hand or on the forehead. And no-one could get a job or even buy in any store without the permit of that mark, which was either the name of the Creature or the code number of his name''.

For emotional claptrap, it is hard to go past the present debate on an identity card. There has seldom been a subject on which there has been so much misunderstanding, so much misrepresentation and so much downright irrational fear.
You would think that no Australian had ever been given a number; that drivers' licences, passport, credit cards and tax file number still had to be invented.

People are scared of numbers. I realise that a vast proportion of the Australian population is innumerate. I have mentioned that on many occasions in this House when I have spoken about our education system. Because we talk about a number, this fear is put into people. I cannot understand why it is terribly different to give a person a number rather than use his name. There is no doubt that the Government is currently losing the argument by saying that information given to governments is safe and will not be leaked. I do not believe that for one minute. Any information given to governments or to anybody possibly will be leaked. There will be unauthorised access no matter how many bits of legislation we pass to prevent it. The important point to put is that with the identity card there will be no new information on people. If a person registers himself for inclusion on the electoral roll, he has to give the same sort of information-in fact, more information than he will have to give to obtain an identity card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or if you want to borrow money.

—Certainly if he wants to borrow money. Some people who are allegedly concerned about privacy are utterly hypocritical. Frank Costigan, QC, comes up as an upholder of civil liberties and privacy. He conducted an extremely slipshod inquiry which hurt the civil liberties of many people in Australia. He and his staff leaked to the media and worked with the late National Times. There is no doubt about that. He is allegedly concerned with privacy, yet he advocated very widespread telephone tapping. He advocated that all police forces should have the right to tap phones. He advocated that there should be all kinds of interference with privacy. Yet he worries about the Australia Card. We have the hypocrisy of the sort of people who were associated with the National Times. They complain about the possibility of interference with privacy but they were prepared to publish transcripts of illegal phone taps. What utter hypocrisy it is for those sorts of people to behave in this way. Honourable members opposite supported that concept at odd times. I am not saying that all honourable members opposite supported the publication of transcripts of illegal phone taps, but many did.

SPEECH.PARA: In a different spectrum, many academics oppose the proposition of the identification card. However, the same academics have made representations to me, and I am certain to many Ministers-possibly the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table-that they want to increase the sort of information that must be given by Australians for census purposes. They want more and more information so they can publish more and more papers about the private behaviour of Australians. The information that is required for the ID card is completely non-intrusive, but academics want private information for census purposes and they oppose the current destruction of census forms. Currently the forms are destroyed to ensure people's privacy. All we do is take the information without taking the name of the person who has given the information. The complete and utter hypocrisy of some of those people amazes me.

For some weeks the people running the campaign against the so-called Australia Card were the only ones making the running. Slowly other people have become upset, if nothing else, by the utter hysteria that has been created. I will quote some of the people who have given a more rational view. An Australian Financial Review commentator called Peter Ruehl-I do not know the gentleman but he seems to write a reasonable column-stated:

The current wave of paranoia over the proposed Australia Card has the basic ingredients for a classic battle in this vein. First, you must have an issue that has all the relevance, in societal terms, of, say, the Lindy Chamberlain case. Second, the presence of a small gaggle of monomaniacs is required to insure sanity doesn't prevail too quickly.
That is a perfect summing up of what is happening in the discussion currently. David Potts-I think that he is the economics editor of the Australian-put this rational point:
OK, so there are other alternatives to the ID card. But how different are they?

Obviously I am not entitled to speak on behalf of the Government and I have not discussed it with any member of the Government, but I would not be surprised if, in the end, we came to some compromise about using taxation file numbers for which honourable members opposite are pushing. What is the difference? Mr Potts continued:
Many have suggested that it would be better to use our tax file numbers when opening a bank account and the like. For this to work, the bank would have to know the number you have given is genuine.

But how does it find out? By ringing the Tax Office? How do we know what the Tax Office tells it? Do you want the bank to find out how much you owe in tax? Which government department knows more about you than any other?

Alternatively, there would have to be some certifiable card or piece of paper with your tax file number on it, in which case there'd be no difference between it and the ID card except perhaps the number or the design.
Besides, if the whole point of the exercise is to stop tax avoidance, what happens to the people who don't have a tax file number because they've never paid tax. Are they still let off scot free?

Appropriately, the title of Alan Mitchell's column in the Sydney Morning Herald is `The crazies against the ID Card'. First, he refers to Dr Shepherd, and Ben Lexcen who fears for the future of European Australia. Apparently it will be all right for the Aborigines. He writes:
Oh, and Mr Howard, who also fears for the future liberty and privacy, warns that the Australia Card would impose an enormous extra cost on small business.

I suspect Mr Howard is right about small business-because small business is where most of the tax evasion occurs. The last major anti-evasion measure targeted at small business-Mr Howard's Prescribed Payments System-has netted a small army of new taxpayers and a fortune in previously-evaded tax, much of it from the building industry.
I will leave part of the column out where he gives a serve to the Australian Chamber of Commerce. The article goes on:

What information do they imagine the Government would have that it does not have now? The Tax Office would be better informed. But it would have no information that either it is not entitled to under the present law or that it would not be entitled to under the alternative proposed by another leader of the campaign against the Australia Card, Senator Janine Haines.
One can only expect the Australian Democrats to be involved in any irrational and populist campaign because they are the experts on irrational populism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say it again.

—I would be happy to repeat it. I suppose most people in this chamber at least would agree with it and I suppose the majority of those in the other chamber would too. Tom Connors in the Canberra Times of last Sunday week, said:

SPEECH.PARA: You'll have to excuse me, but I am not going hysterical over the possible introduction of the Australia Card. Furthermore, I am not impressed by the weird coalition of Far Right, Far Left and Centre who are conjuring up the spectre of a police state and the end of the Australian way of life as we know it.

The fact that people like the Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, the Rugby coach and Far Right supermouth Alan Jones, and some people on the loony Left oppose the card should induce more to look for virtues in it.
We have extremists, people who can always see terrible things--

TALK.START.PARA: —Joan Coxsedge.

—Exactly. She thinks it is an American plot; somebody else thinks it is all a Russian plot. We have idiots. I do not usually agree with Don Chipp, but this is what an article in last Sunday's paper said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Don Chipp . . . yesterday said he thought the issue-
that is, the issue of the Australia Card-
did not warrant the ``obsessive'' debate it was receiving from his party-
that is, the Democrats-
and others.
Mr Chipp . . . : ``Too often the wrong things are on the agenda up here in Canberra. Today we seem to be obsessed with the Australia Card.
``I don't think Australia will go down the tube if we have an Australia Card or don't have an Australia Card''.
``I think I was probably one of the first members of Parliament to suggest an Australia Card. This was about eight or nine years ago.

I do not know whether Janine Haines has read this comment, but I am sure she will not quote it. Anne Summers who has returned-I think only temporarily-from the United States said in yesterday's Times on Sunday:
My identification number is-
and she gives the number-

I need it to get paid, to open a bank account, to sign a lease, to claim medical benefits, or to apply for a credit card. It is my US Social Security number, and having lived in the US for almost two years now I confess that I am not only used to it but, even though I can never remember the number without consulting the card, I do not find it much of an intrusion on my liberty.

Perhaps because I have been out of Australia for a while I confess to not being able to understand the passions that have been directed into opposing the Australia Card. Perhaps because I have become used to having an ID card I cannot appreciate the extraordinary paranoia its proposed introduction has aroused.
I am sure all honourable members have received exceptionally literate votergrams from constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you open them?

—Yes, I even open them. I have one here but I will not give the person's name because it may be someone pretending to be him. I often write to someone and say somebody is pretending, and I think this should be checked because the man is an idiot and it is a bit rough. But listen to this; this is supposed to convince me:

SPEECH.PARA: Cancel certain citizens right-dark side Australia Card. Low interest housing works. Make dole repayable-thumb print tax number. Discipline young, save 25%, voucher education. Re-invest privatization, don't revenue. Semi-privatize defence equipment. Simulators aren't secret, nor is pilferage.

It is signed. It is a convincing letter for many, obviously, in this House, but it is not convincing to me. I would like to make the point again that whether one believes that the ID card is the best possible way of dealing with taxation avoidance and social security fraud or not, let us have a rational argument about it; let us not get involved with groups of people who do not believe in democracy, who do not believe in rational argument, who do not believe in any of the sorts of things that a civilised parliament ought to be standing for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last thing I was going to speak on in the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 tonight was the ID card. But as one of those people whom the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) obviously believes are either paranoid or belong to a fringe group, I say that for the last four weeks I have been around Australia in my capacity as chairman of the Opposition's ID card task force. I hope that some of the work that we have been doing has been fairly rational in terms of the debate that has been going on. I personally do not think that tremendous tide of public opinion that is now starting to swing towards the Government is public opinion that is made up of people who might be paranoid or off the planet. I am really quite surprised that the honourable member for Prospect has come up with some of the arguments that he has, because I have very great respect for him. I know of his role in the Council for Civil Liberties. I have been on platforms with representatives of councils of civil liberties around Australia in recent days and I think that those people could be far from being called paranoiac. In fact, their debate, to my mind, has been particularly rational.

SPEECH.PARA: There are definitely some very real questions that must be asked by all Australians concerning the introduction of this ID card, least of all being the cost effective nature of it. I think a great number on this side of the House have some very grave doubts about whether we should be running around spending $800m to $1 billion to get the wretched thing set up. I think there is a very real concern in the community when we are continually told by Senator Ryan that this particular system that we have is based on the Swedish system. I know that a number of my colleagues have expressed to me their concern about the way the Swedish system has gone. Sweden has had an identity card system for no less than 20 years. For the last 10 to 12 years the whole place has been a disaster. It has been a fact that the Swedes cannot guarantee the security of their system. What started as a humble identity card, as that card which Senator Ryan tells us will contain only our photograph, our name, our signature, and our date of birth, has developed into quite a monster. I quote from the report of the Privacy Foundation. It sets out the cases that exist in Sweden It says:

In Sweden the social code numbers float around everywhere. They are used by libraries and bookclubs, by credit card companies and insurance companies, they turn up on all sorts of private and public identity cards, public transport cards . . . your football club, your chess club and the political party you belong to all take up your social code number. Every Swedish citizen is caught in a cobweb of computerised information, just waiting for the spider.

Of course the spider has got in; so much so in fact that the head of the Swedish Data Inspection Agency, Jan Freese, resigned in recent days because he could no longer guarantee the security of that Swedish data bank. He got out when the bureaucrats got into the system, unbeknown to the authority. He got out when the Government decided that it would scrap the whole idea of a census and just hit button A on the computer when all the information about Swedish society would come up. We know what has happened there, too. It is not only the bureaucracy that has gone mad with the information. In fact, the bureaucracy has sold it off to public companies.

The whole thing is an absolute disaster in Sweden, so much so that if a policeman stops a person's car there he can, in a few seconds, by typing the car registration number and the ID card number on to a portable terminal, get a huge amount of data about the person. He can get his name, age, address, whether he is married, his profession, income, taxes and whether they are paid or not, whether the person has been searched or has been in prison, if his driving licence is not in order-any sort of information can come up on the portable machine attached to it. One might use the old argument that one has nothing to hide, but I am damned if I want a situation in Australia where we can develop into a case where, whenever one got pulled up by a traffic policeman, he can get that information about one.

We are told time and time again in this ID card debate that there will be a dedicated landline system to feed the information around Australia. I still have not got a reply from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) about what form that dedicated landline is going to take. That landline is going to add an additional $10 billion to the cost of the implementation of the ID card in Australia. As I said the other day, that particular building project to hook up all those terminals around Australia is going to be a bigger construction job than building the pyramids, if we are to have dedicated landlines. There will be funny little people running around the length and breadth of Australia digging trenches to put in the dedicated landline.

The big problem with the dedicated landline is that it is territorial in its aspect and if one is going to crack it, that is the easiest way to go. I would love to tell the story of what happened to me during a recent visit to Townsville, where we went and checked out the dedicated landline systems that operated into a certain bank there. It is so ridiculous. We walked up the laneway of this particular bank, there was what looked like a switchbox on the wall, we picked up the flap and there were the dedicated landlines. It said so and so bank, Townsville. The whole of the bank computer system sits there on the side of the wall. People have got to realise that these things are not secure.

I think it is probably a reasonable argument when people say that they have nothing to hide and for that reason they do not object to the ID card, but the one thing that we must stress time and time again in this whole debate about the ID card is that it is that number which is the key to the lock that will give all that information. In terms of the argument that we have at the moment and the information that might be supplied here at the moment, it may not be so bad, but if one goes down the track and follows that Swedish experience-the trouble is that people get used to using the cards, as Dr Anne Summers said in her article-there will not be an aspect of Australian life that will not be touched by the ID card. That is one of the great dangers. There is no doubt about it, whether one says that it is hysterical or not, that there is in the sensible rational Australian community at the moment, a real feeling of concern about the ID card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Immense concern.

—Incredible concern. The honourable member for Kennedy and I are going to Mount Isa this weekend to speak to constituents of his about some of the aspects of this legislation. That is the depth of the concern. It has come from as far away as Mount Isa-the length and breadth of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is not helping its argument. We came in here last Friday, and I asked a question of the Minister for Community Services and Health about whether or not it was a fact of life that sporting clubs, the Country Women's Association, Rotary, Apex and the Lions, and service clubs within our community would have to have a number. Those clubs do have to have an ID card number. We will also have to have a situation where the secretary or treasurer, or both, of those particular organisations will be required to register not only the club's numbers but their own number with their tax file information. What is even more horrific is that, every year, after the annual general meeting of the clubs, they will have 14 days, according to Government legislation, to go and change over the details-this is the answer of the Minister in Hansard for last Friday-otherwise they are up for a fine of up to $5,000 or six months gaol or both. What the devil is Australia coming to when we are getting into that sort of situation? I wonder, in this debate, how well the Government has thought it out.

We had the other spectre in Question Time today when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was asked a question by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) about whether or not State banks had to comply with the requirements of the Australia Card legislation. Obviously, the Treasurer did not know, although all he had to do was go and read the Constitution of Australia, which says that while the Commonwealth Government has the right to put on terms and conditions on the operations of State banks in areas other than their home State, it has no control over the banks. Are we really going to get to the farcical situation where the State banks in the capital cities of Australia will become tax shelters for the crooks? They may do, but has the Government thought this out?

It is all very well for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to come in here and say that he has a mandate, but I do not believe that on an issue as major as this, with such far reaching complications and concerns within the community, we should be rushing headlong into a system such as this.

The thing that annoys me more than anything else is the fact that under this system, ordinary decent everyday Australians are going to be presumed guilty by virtue of the ID card, and it is going to be their responsibility to prove their innocence before the Government will accept them. I think that that is a blight on Australia. I am no friend of tax cheats or dole bludgers but I am certainly not looking forward to a situation like this, where all Australians will be lined up and photographed to get this wretched identity card system into place. I do not believe that within the Australian community at the moment, decent, fair-minded rational Australians want a part of this legislation.

I really get quite frustrated when I turn to the Treasurer's Budget Speech-after all we are debating the Appropriation Bill tonight. In his Speech, the Treasurer started talking about the Australia Card, and how:
. . . the system will return $1,000 million a year in revenue that is presently being evaded or defrauded.
In the next paragraph he said:

To further reinforce our anti-avoidance measures, this Budget will fund the Tax Office to establish special audit teams of highly qualified and experienced officers to mount more effective and detailed scrutinies of potential tax avoidance activities, particularly in the corporate sector.

The Government has the ID card on the one hand and the Treasurer turns round and gives the solution in the next paragraph. It already has that system to go after the funny money, and nobody in the Government has yet told me just how the ID card is going to bring in that black economy, that cash economy where the real fraud takes place in our community today.

I will not spend any more time on the ID card debate, because I think that the Government will find that over the next few months the ID card will come up more and more in every type of debate in the House, and I think that it will really feel the lash of public opinion against it as more and more people realise just what is involved in this national identity card system. Without sounding round the bend, let me say that I really do not think that in a democracy such as ours, in a common law country such as ours, the ID card is the answer to half these problems.

Tonight I was going to speak about some of the aspects about the 1988 Budget presented by the Treasurer last Tuesday night. I will now have to cut down my comments on it. Let me say that the one thing that came through to me in the Budget of last Tuesday night was that there was one sector of Australians who missed out on that Budget. The Treasurer came in here and told us that we had a balanced Budget, and we learnt about the special help that is to be given to a great number of underprivileged people in our community. I am sure that most members of the Opposition will applaud that, and particularly the help that is to be given to the poor children of Australia, but there is a very big group of Australians at the moment who seem to have been forgotten by this Government in particular and governments around Australia and that is middle Australia. They are the people that so many of us represent in this House. They are the young married couples who, frankly, are now struggling for survival on what we would call reasonable incomes. They are the people in my electorate who have been hit by the highest interest rates in Australia's history. I suppose we applaud the fact that some of those interest rates are now coming down. But the plain facts are that right now in Australia we have the second highest interest rates in our history. I think the struggle that is going on in the average suburban Australian family and the pressures that are being put on the average suburban Australian family by the policies that have come from this Government are quite horrendous and particularly need our attention.

In my electorate at the moment people are actually walking out of their homes. All of a sudden they find that they just cannot maintain the payments on ordinary, average suburban homes. It is not happening in one or two cases, it is happening in dozens of cases in the southern and eastern suburbs of Brisbane. The pressure that is put on marriages and the number of marriage breakups are really putting tremendous pressure on the social fabric of Australia. I hope that as this year goes on we will be looking at a more compassionate attitude by the Government to the people who really have been neglected for years-the people who are on a single income; the people on an income of about $25,000 a year who are trying to educate one or two kiddies; the people who really do not get any specific help from the Government now; and the people who find that they really miss out on any substantial tax benefit as a result of the recent income tax cuts. These people, who really are the backbone of Australia, are finding it very difficult to survive.

In the short period that I have left there are a couple of other matters that I would like to raise in the debate. I do not suppose there would be many in this House who would be more supportive of the tourist industry in Australia and indeed during the last 10 years in this House I have done all I can to promote that industry. I think we are starting to see the benefits of a great deal of work that has been done. It was started by Sir Phillip Lynch when he was the Minister with responsibility for tourism in the Fraser Government and, of course, it has been carried on under this Government. I take nothing away from the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) for some of the work he has done.

There are a couple of aspects which come through in the Budget Papers and which concern me at the moment. They really deal with the future of tourism in Australia. If honourable members go through the Budget Papers-I refer to Budget Paper No. 1-and look at what is happening in terms of assistance to the tourist industry this year, they will see that there is an increase of 19.9 per cent in total funding. That is really not quite a bad effort. It is about $7.6m up on last year. Most of that money, in fact, will go into tourism promotion through the Australian Tourist Commission. If honourable members go further through those documents they will see what else the Government is going to do. One thing that comes through very clearly is the fact that the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS) has only one year to go and then it will be axed by the Government. That scheme has been full of problems. There have been tremendous delays in the Government making payments under that scheme over the last couple of years. Honourable members will find that a great number of the newer tourist operators in the business will be hit very hard by the completion of that scheme. But my appeal tonight is really related to the fact that in the Governor-General's Speech, in the Treasurer's Budget Speech and in the Budget Papers-all the way through-there is a very heavy emphasis on tourism and the very good things it is doing for the Australian community. I applaud that, but I do not think we should ever regard the tourism industry as the panacea for all the problems in Australia. The one thing I am getting a little bit afraid of is that it will become very much the milch cow for the Government if we are not particularly careful.

In the last few minutes I will cite a couple of things that concern me. Firstly, TOPS will be axed next year. I am a bit upset about that. Secondly, I am quite astounded that the Government will impose an inbound tax of $5 on everybody entering Australia. Honourable members might say that that is not much, but the cost of collection of that tax which, undoubtedly will fall on the airlines, is millions of dollars a year. That will be reflected in even higher ticket costs into Australia. While this Government refuses really to get a cheap airfare regime into place and to allow charter operators into Australia, we cannot afford to price ourselves out of those markets. I notice that the increased number of tourists will reap for the Government from the departure tax itself a total of $61m for 1987-88. The total expenditure on the tourism industry this year is $46m. That is a fairly big windfall-$16m-which obviously will go into general revenue. I hope that we will be looking to make sure that we do not put so many costs on the tourist industry that we lose our attraction in terms of price for those overseas visitors who are coming here now and spending some very big money.

I am concerned that we are not doing enough, especially in some of the State training establishments, to ensure that we can correctly look after the tourists. I know that Japan is one of our fastest growing markets at the moment. There has been some very real criticism that the Australian industry is not adjusting quickly enough for the Japanese market, that we are not teaching enough people how to speak Japanese and how to treat Japanese tourists coming in. I know that that is basically a job for the State educational authorities. Some Federal funds are going in this year, but I urge the Federal Government to push that line for as long as it possibly can.

In the last few seconds available to me, I also urgently appeal to the Government and to the Australian Tourist Commission not to forget that northern European market which is starting to build up so well. While the concentration has been on Japan, it can be a fairly fickle market. North America can be a reasonably fickle market. When the big spending tourists come to Australia they will, in fact, be coming from Germany, from the Scandinavian countries, from Switzerland and from Holland. I hope that appropriate pressure will be put on the Australian Tourist Commission to go out into those northern European countries and sell Australia as a destination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), is the choice of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) as the head of the Opposition's task force to oppose the Australia Card.
—A good choice.

—The honourable member for Bass suggests by way of interjection that he is a good choice for the job. I suspect that he was chosen for that job because he was one of the few members of the Opposition who were not on record as supporting the introduction of some form of identity card in Australia. The Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and the former Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt)-all those members of the Opposition are on record as having made public statements saying that they believe that the Australia Card proposal is in the interests of the Australian community. It is only in recent days when this weird coalition of extreme Left and extreme Right elements have got together that members of the Opposition have come to the conclusion that they can win a few cheap votes by deciding that they should now oppose the Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the pleasure of addressing a rally on this very issue in the Federal electorate of Robertson last Saturday. The rally was organised by people who are opposed to the Australia Card. The rally was so successful that of the 180,000 residents who live on the New South Wales central coast the roll-up was between 250 and 300 people opposed to the Australia Card. It was a rather disappointing roll-up. The crowd was so aggressive in interjecting and interrupting me when I was speaking and seeking to explain why the Australia Card was necessary that at times I thought I was back at New South Wales Young Labor conferences being interrupted by interjections from members of the Australian Labor Party who would be known to you, Mr Deputy Speaker-members such as Mr Bolton and Mr Mellem. Needless to say, it was important that those people heard the true story. It is a pity the honourable member for Fadden has left the chamber. He also wants to ignore the true story. He does not wish to debate the Australia Card on the facts.

Members of the Opposition have invented a fiction, a fantasy, which they claim is the Australia Card proposal and they quite easily put that over, but that is not the Australia Card proposal which this Government is putting forward. The most important question for anyone who is involved in this debate is: What is on the Australia Card Register? What information goes into the Australia Card computer? As the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) pointed out so clearly in his excellent contribution to this debate-I only wish that he had been with me at Gosford last Saturday-individuals' names, addresses, dates of birth, sex and places of employment will be on the card Register. That is information which is given to the Electoral Commission when anyone fills out an electoral enrolment card.

Earlier the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) pointed out that when anyone applies for a loan from a bank or other lending institution, he is required to provide a great deal of additional information, information which we are not seeking to obtain from citizens when they obtain an Australia Card. We do not want to know what their assets are. We do not want to know the names of referees who will vouch for who they are.

So, first of all, the information in the Australia Card computer is not a person's tax records or any information on applications for social security benefits, and it is certainly not any information about a person's medical treatment. The computer record simply contains a person's name, address, date of birth, sex and place of employment.

Many people have also been given false information as to when they will be required to produce their Australia Card. The average citizen would, I believe, be required to produce the Australia Card only in three situations, which would be encountered on very rare occasions. If people change their employment and obtain a new job, they would be asked to produce the Australia Card on the first day that they show up, or, if they forgot it the first day, they can show it on the second day, or the third, and so on. Even if an employee refuses to front up and show his card, well and good: the Government says, `You are not banned from employment but your employer will simply deduct the maximum rate of tax, 50c in the dollar, to make sure that you are paying your fair share of tax'. That ensures that people who are, perhaps, working under false names in second jobs to minimise tax pay their fair share of tax-and who can object to that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair enough.

—That is fair enough, as the honourable member for Lilley says. The second occasion on which a citizen would be required to produce the Australia Card would be if that person sought to open a new bank account. It is quite common these days to hear of people who have opened bank accounts in false names, often to ensure that they do not have to declare interest which perhaps might be earned on that account as taxable income. The third occasion when a citizen would be required to produce the card would be if he or she were after some support or assistance from the Department of Social Security.

SPEECH.PARA: To hear Opposition members, such as the honourable member for Fadden, suggesting that a policeman can pull a person over to the side of the road, demand to see his Australia Card and then proceed to obtain all sorts of information on that person's assets, any offences he might have committed and details about his medical life, is to hear a fantasy of their imagination. Policemen will not be able to demand to see one's Australia Card. If a policeman pulls a citizen over to the side of the road and demands to see his Australia Card, that policeman has committed an offence under the Australia Card legislation. That policeman would be liable to a term of imprisonment of up to several years if found guilty.

The honourable member for Fadden also delights in suggesting that everyone will have access to the information which will be in the Australia Card computer. He suggested that it would be quite easy for anyone to tap into the computer and obtain the information which has been provided by ordinary citizens. If that is so, one might ask: Why have people not tapped into the computer databases which are already up and running in, for example, the Australian Taxation Office or the Department of Social Security, or the Health Insurance Commission's Medicare computer? Every Medicare office has terminals which are linked to the Medicare computer database. I imagine that if people could tap into the Medicare computer, it would be just as easy for them to tap into the Australia Card computer.

The fact is that the lines provided for the Medicare computer are dedicated lines which are secure, just as many facilities provided by Telecom are secure. If someone breaks into a Telecom exchange to seek to install an interception device on a Medicare computer line or any other computer line, as soon as the entrance door to that exchange is opened an alarm goes off at a central exchange in the Telecom system, which alerts the Telecom staff to the fact that an illegal entry has occurred. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, as a former Telecom technician yourself, will be aware of the very strict security procedures which Telecom enforces in the system. In the previous Parliament, when I served on the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception, we were advised by senior Telecom staff from Victoria that they had very strict procedures on security at Telecom exchanges.

In the time left to me tonight I want to touch on several other issues. The first concerns another matter involving the communications area, and that is the establishment of a UHF translator to provide improved television reception in Wyong Shire, which makes up over 80 per cent of my electorate. During the 1984 election campaign, the then Minister for Communications, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), was on the Central Coast and announced at that time that he had agreed to the establishment of translators on the Central Coast so that residents there could receive not only Channel 3 from Newcastle but also commercial channels, 7, 9 and 10 from the Sydney television region, plus Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) signals. The Minister was breaking new ground there, because in the past areas had to be classified as belonging to either the metropolitan area, which would have restricted us to channels 7, 9 and 10, or, in this case, to the Newcastle service area, in which case we would have been entitled to receive only Channel 3. So the good news was that Minister Duffy announced that we would have an overlapping service area and would be able to receive four commercial channels as well as the ABC and SBS signals.

On 24 April 1986 Minister Duffy was on the Central Coast and officially opened the first of a planned three translators there which were going to implement the announcement he had made in 1984. The first translator was at Rumbalara Reserve at Gosford. At that official opening ceremony, the Minister announced that the second and third UHF translators, which were to be established at Wyrrabalong trigonometry station at Forresters Beach and at Boudi National Park, would be running within 12 months.

It has been more than 12 months since the Minister told us that he expected the other two UHF translators to be up and operating, but I am sorry to report to the House tonight that very little progress has been made in the establishment of the translators. As a result of that, constituents in my electorate can look forward to having fuzzy television reception and very poor reception for some time to come. I am raising this matter tonight in the hope that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) will ensure that his Department investigates this matter thoroughly. At present there is a dispute between Gosford City Council and the consortium of television stations which is constructing the UHF translator at Forresters Beach. In March 1985 Gosford City Council gave approval for the television station consortium to construct a translator at Wyrrabalong, at Forresters Beach. As you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will be familiar with that part of the Central Coast, I am sure that you are aware that Wyrrabalong is a very dominant peak on the Central Coast's coastline.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it well.
—The Leader of the Opposition and I know it very well.
—The Leader of the Opposition claims to know it well. Perhaps he has gone hang-gliding there with some of the hang-gliders who frequent the area.
—I have not quite graduated to that but I am working on it.

—I would be happy to arrange for the Leader of the Opposition to have a go at hang-gliding there any time he wishes. In March 1985 Gosford City Council gave approval for the translator mast to be erected at Wyrrabalong. The proposal put forward by the television station consortium was for the erection of a lighthouse-type structure. What has happened since is that the consortium has concluded that that is too expensive, and it now wishes to erect a simple transmission tower of lattice-type structure, which would obviously be a lot cheaper, but that would not be agreed to by Gosford City Council. As a result there is stalemate or stand-off between Gosford City Council and the consortium of television stations. I am not too clear who is in the right or the wrong. The television station consortium originally agreed to the erection of this lighthouse-type structure even though it was more expensive, yet Gosford City Council has not been prepared to give an inch and perhaps bend a little to allow the television stations to proceed with the erection of this tower.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that the Gosford City Council has no incentive to hurry the erection of this translator because the ratepayers and residents of Gosford city will not benefit from any improved reception which results from the erection of the UHF translator at Wyrrabalong. Many Wyong shire residents suffer very poor television reception because this stalemate is continuing. I believe that the Department of Transport and Communications now has a responsibility to intervene, to knock a few heads together to seek to ensure that Gosford City Council and the consortium of television stations can sort this problem out so that my constituents can obtain the television reception which they were promised as soon as possible.

On the very question of the environmental significance of Wyrrabalong and the erection of a lighthouse or a lattice type structure at Wyrrabalong, I think it is important for the Department of Transport and Communications perhaps to consult with the local interest groups such as the Bateau Bay Progress Association, whose officers have contacted me and said that they are not particularly concerned whether it is a lighthouse or a lattice-type structure; what they are more concerned about is the public access and landscaping which was promised by the television consortium and the fact that this will provide greater public access to the beautiful coastal strip which runs from Crack Neck lookout to Wyrrabalong trigonometry station.

I turn to another area of government administration addressed in the Appropriation Bill; that is, the drug offensive and the Government's decision to plough a great deal of money into fighting drugs wherever possible. The Government's campaign against drug abuse is a three-pronged effort. First of all, we have sought to raise the consciousness of ordinary Australians about the harmful effects of legal and illegal drugs. Many honourable members in the House tonight would have seen the advertisements on television explaining in very graphic terms the effect drugs can have on the health of ordinary people. A second area has been the increase in funds which we have provided for rehabilitation centres. The third and most important area is the funds we have provided for the education of children, particularly young children, to seek to ensure that there is a smaller probability of children becoming addicted to drugs in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very important.

—As the honourable member for Lilley suggests, it is a very important area. A lot of Federal Government funds provided in this area have gone to the Life Education Movement, which was started by the Reverend Ted Noffs, who is currently in poor health. I am sure all honourable members in this House would be wishing him a speedy recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the pleasure of organising a half-day itinerary for a visiting group of Chinese citizens representing the All China Youth Federation when they were visiting Sydney recently. I had to pick out something that perhaps would be of interest to them to visit in Sydney. Having had quite a bit to do with the Life Education centres in my electorate, I came to the conclusion that perhaps the best thing the Chinese people could see would be the Life Education Centre at Potts Point. That was arranged and these citizens of China who were visiting Australia as guests of the Australian Political Exchange Committee one morning visited the Life Education Centre at Potts Point. Mr Wesley Noffs, the son of Ted Noffs and the National Director of the Life Education Movement, went to a great deal of trouble to make our Chinese visitors feel at home. He had learnt a little bit of Mandarin and had a speech translated into Mandarin. That was greatly appreciated by our Chinese visitors. They were very moved by the classes of young children whom they were able to sit with to experience the very clever way in which the Life Education courses can explain to young people that they do have the right to refuse any drugs offered to them whether by adults or even their best friends. They are taught to develop their self-respect so that they are able to say no to their friends even if their friends wish to smoke, drink or use harder drugs such as heroin.

In my electorate last Saturday the Central Coast Life Education Movement officially launched its second mobile van. The launching was attended by the Deputy Leader of the New South Wales State Opposition, Mr Collins, the State member for Willoughby, and by my State parliamentary colleague, Mr McGowan. The Central Coast Life Education Movement continues to make a great contribution on the Central Coast in educating primary school children in the Federal electorates of Robertson and Dobell, ensuring that they are aware of the horrible effects of drugs. More than that, it ensures that they have the strength within themselves to say no and to keep off illegal and legal drugs. I have great pleasure in supporting this part of the Government's Budget, which I am sure will help many children for years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the first thing I would like to do is to congratulate you on your re-election as Chairman of Committees of this House. No doubt you will carry out your onerous tasks in your usual manner. Tonight, I am speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88. In doing so I would like first of all to welcome the fact that the Budget at long last has been balanced. I do not congratulate the Government for doing that but I welcome it because I believe it should have been done years ago. As a person in business in rural Queensland, I welcome it because I believe that now we have a freed-up monetary system, it is absolutely essential-Keynesian-type economics of deficit spending is not working throughout the world-that we continue not only this year but also in the foreseeable future to have a balanced Budget because we must take pressure off interest rates, particularly the domestic interest rates, which we control. It is absolutely important that the Federal Government, which is the biggest borrower-I will deal later with the Australian Wheat Board, which is the second biggest borrower in Australia-is now not in the market but it still has to appropriate large sums of money to pay back interest on previous borrowings, with which we totally disagree. Since this Labor Government was elected to govern Australia we have seen it go out into both the domestic and foreign markets and borrow $30 billion to prop up its Budget arrangements until this time. At long last it has stopped doing that but it still has to repay up to $7.8 billion annually. Of course, that is not going to decrease unless the Government pays back the $1 billion it has promised to pay back from the sale of assets, although I cannot find anywhere in the Budget Papers where it is shown that that is going to happen. Maybe seeing is believing; maybe it will happen. Along with most other people on this side of the House, the things that still concern me are that debt and the balance of payments situation. We have seen a rapid growth in that area while the Labor Government has been in office. We are now looking at a figure estimated at $11.5 billion. We have to be encouraged to increase capital investment if we are going to get that figure down. We have to create more jobs, expand our base, our gross domestic product, so that we can all show a greater profit and get back into balance. Unfortunately, we will probably have to restrict imports and continue to increase exports. Our exports in volume are actually increasing but the price we have been getting for our products on the world market is down.

SPEECH.PARA: We must increase our capital investment, and that is one thing that this Government has not done for Australia since it was elected. There has been no significant increase in capital investment, although we have seen the Government do a 100 per cent somersault and reintroduce negative gearing. However, it has also reduced the depreciation allowance on new buildings from 4 to 2 1/2 per cent, which really mitigates the negative gearing arrangement. We have seen the distortions of the great capital gains tax the Government has introduced. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had a great idea. Someone rang him up while he was in Western Australia, and he thought it was a good idea to eliminate the provision of housing by introducing a capital gains tax. I am pleased to see that even some of the Ministers on his side of politics agree that housing should never have been eliminated in this way, but as in all taxation arrangements we see a distortion in that area. This has led to enormous prices being paid not just in Sydney but throughout Australia. We said at the time that that would happen, that people would start spending inordinate amounts on their private homes to avoid paying capital gains tax. This is not to say that we support a capital gains tax; we believe it ought to be abolished. That is the only way we will get capital investment up and moving again. If there is no incentive for people to invest; if they cannot make a profit by investing and selling, they will not do it. It is as simple as that. We operate on the profit motive. Profit has become a dirty word to those on the Government side, but that is the only way we will get this country up and running again. I am strongly of the view that interest rates will come down and stay down with a balanced Budget, and certainly that will help.

The States also have to be pulled into line and they must stop borrowing, as must local government. As the Opposition's spokesman for local government, I know that this is an important area we have to deal with because it is the grass roots of politics in Australia. I have always been pretty tough on local governments; I believe a lot of them have gone out and borrowed too much money and, for organisations at that level, are living beyond their means. The States are doing the same, as is the Commonwealth. We know of the massive amounts that have been borrowed overseas, such as the $30 billion we have heard about, to keep us living--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you tell them that?

—Yes, I do tell them that. I spent nine years as a councillor of the Tara Shire. That shire was actually very good. A lot of councils cannot even pay their interest and redemption with the rates they collect. That is the position they have put themselves in. Some of them spend their total rate collections on interest and redemption payments on loans they have taken out in the previous 5, 6, 7 or 8 years. That is something we must be more responsible about. I am quite happy to tell them about it. If we are not producing and selling the goods to enjoy the standards of the lucky country, the sorts of living standards we have become used to, we have to pull our horns in for a while and make sure that we stop borrowing our way into prosperity. In the end it will not be us who pay for it; it will be our children. I have three sons and a daughter who will be out there working and I do not wish to place the sort of burden on them that Labor governments, during the Whitlam years in particular, have certainly placed on Australia. I believe that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) undertook his role of Treasurer very responsibly because most times he balanced the Budget, and he did not overspend. We were living within our means at that time.
—What do you mean `most times he balanced the Budget'?

—Most times; it was only the last year that he did not. Honourable members should look at the figures, and I have often said to the Leader of the Opposition himself that he should look at the figures. I believe he did an excellent job, and Malcolm Fraser was a good old Scottish Prime Minister; he did not waste money. If one looks at the real Budget figures for those years I believe one can see there was really responsible monetary management-much more responsible than what we have seen in the last few years.

SPEECH.PARA: We see now that the Reserve Bank of Australia made a profit this year of $2 1/2 billion, following a profit last year of $2 billion. The people who have paid for that profit have been the primary producers and small business people of Australia, who have been paying interest rates of up to 25 per cent. That sort of nonsense has to stop too. We freed up the so-called money market and yet this Government has been using the Reserve Bank for the last three or four years to prop up the dollar. The overseas speculators have been making the money but the real producers of this country, the farmers and small business people, have been paying the costs of the Reserve Bank's profits which this Government is now using to help, as it claims, balance its Budget.

The Government says it will sell off assets, but of course we have not seen anything sold yet. The Government was going to sell the airports at $350m but they have been taken off the list of sales. I will attend some of the auctions when they take place although I will be surprised if any do. An amount of $1 billion has been provided for in the Budget to help balance it up, but I think the Government will have difficulty because I do not know who will buy these assets. I do not know who is looking for a dry dock in Sydney, and there is also one in Brisbane that has just closed and is for sale. I am amazed to think who the Government believes will buy these things. I assure the Government that it will be pretty difficult to sell some of these so-called assets it has listed for sale.

In my area of responsibility, local government, we have seen a cut in expenditure allocations to councils. The figures have been announced, and in Queensland 11 councils are to be paid less than last year. The real increase in spending of 2 per cent that is given back from Federal taxes has been cut, and we have seen a new direction whereby the Government has taken a political position within each State to fund particular areas, I guess areas of influence in the Labor Government, so we are seeing tremendous disparity. This is happening not only in Queensland but also in Victoria, where 50 councils are disadvantaged, and following the announcement yesterday of New South Wales's funding we see that nine councils are disadvantaged. They are not getting the sorts of funds they have been used to getting. I believe that we ought to be at least maintaining the level. We do not necessarily need to go much beyond the inflation rate, but councils ought at least to be given sufficient funds to cover their set expenditure carried over from the previous year, including the in-built cost of inflation. Of course, in a number of areas the Government is not even prepared to do that.

We have seen also a decrease in community employment program funding. There has been a cut of 53 per cent, down to $95m to State funding for the program, which will severely affect the operations of local councils. The Government has set up a program upon which the councils have become dependent and all of a sudden, bang, it pulls the rug out from underneath them and they have no funds, no work programs going, and these people who have been employed under these programs are back in the dole queues. The Government is still spending money in that area; there has been no decrease in the rate of unemployment in this country for the last 10 years and we will not get any decrease until we lift that percentage of capital investment. That is a task that seems to have eluded us. There is certainly no such proposal in this Budget, nor has there been in the last three or four for which the Labor Party has been responsible.

We also see the status quo in regard to road funding. There has been no increase in road funding to local government for the last three years. The Labor Party gave it a reasonable increase back in 1983 but since then there has been no real increase, and of course the amount of funding government at that level receives has severely restricted its ability to employ people and construct roads. I am strongly of the view that if we are going to increase our exports, we must maintain our infrastructure. There is no point in letting our docks, roads, railways and coal mines-we heard about coal today-fall to pieces if we are to get out of the mess we have placed ourselves in over the last few years. If one drives around the country, as we all do in our electorates, one cannot help but agree that our roads system is in dire need of upgrading, or at least maintaining. Most of Australia's rural roads are not even being maintained at a reasonable level.

There is an increase in social welfare spending in this Budget of $2 billion over last year. We are squandering money in this area. I agree with Senator Walsh's pronouncements of late that we need to look at child minding funding, at unmarried mothers benefits and all of the nonsense we have been carrying on with for the last five or six years. We have been wasting funds on welfare. It is not hard to see the figure-there has been a net increase of $2 billion in welfare payments. Meanwhile, the roads fall to bits, the fences fall over and the farms and factories generally fall apart. We wonder why we cannot improve our terms of trade situation. The reason is that we are not directing our resources in the right direction. We are directing them into unproductive areas, not productive areas. Until we turn things around and get rid of this Government and get a government back in place that is prepared to do that, Australia will continue to fall slowly into the mire that this Government has created.

The other thing we have seen is a decrease in the land transport program of the present number of cents per litre that have been allocated to road funding. Legislation will be introduced into the House shortly that will reduce that allocation by 0.7c per litre, another broken promise by the Government. This program will not get the funding that was expected.

Rural industry is a very important facet of my electorate of Maranoa. The subsidy scheme for fuel cartage has been cut practically down to nothing and we may as well not have it. This program was introduced by the Liberal-National Party some years ago, again to help decentralisation and to help production in rural areas. All we have seen from this Government is a rapid increase in the taxation on fuel, a totally regressive taxation. It is a taxation on produced items of need. It is essential for us today to use petroleum products in all our production endeavours. We have seen this Government take the excise from 6c a litre to 20c a litre. There has been a transfer of well head taxation to excise at the pump. The total tax take from fuel is about $7 billion--

TALK.START.PARA: —Far too much; give it to the farmers.

—It is much too much. I am not saying that it should all go to farmers but there is certainly a need for a redirection of those taxes. We have to take taxes off the productive inputs if we are to compete with the rest of the world. We pay nearly as much for diesel and petrol in this country as the Americans pay per gallon for their fuel. They are still using the old United States gallon, but one can still buy petrol in America for about 70c to 80c a gallon. Yet in this country we are now seeing prices going up to over 60c a litre. I have paid 62c a litre and I have seen fuel being sold for 63c a litre. Sixty per cent of that charge is taxation. We have seen an enormous hike in prices and the Australian Labor Party appears to be prepared to place a continuous tax upon us. We have to pay this tax because it is there and we need to get fuel. Once we buy a motor car we have to get it from point A to point B. Once we buy a tractor and start running it round a paddock it just so happens that we have to put petroleum into it. It will not run on water, unfortunately.
—There is a fair bit of profiteering as well by the oil companies.
—I do not know about that.
—Well there is, as well as the taxation.

—All right. Perhaps we have to tax these people. I am not frightened of making a bit of a profit. It is amazing how anybody who makes a profit always has to pay some tax in the long run. The more one can turn over a dollar and the more one can make a profit on it the more the Government benefits. I do not hide from profits. I believe that that is what we are on about and we ought to make some. The more we make the better and the wealthier we will become as a nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, primary industry has been attacked as usual. Because the wool industry has had the first price increase for 15 years the $10m that the Government promised for wool promotion has gone. The only reason we got an increase in wool prices is that the Australian Wool Corporation and the growers, dollar for dollar, have had the guts to go out and spend some money on research and promotion. This has encouraged countries throughout the world to start buying our wool again. The Chinese and the people who are buying our wool are processing it and selling it back to us and to the Americans.

There is no government allocation-not 1c-to the beef industry for the chemical residue problem. The Government has been harping about the fact that we are causing this problem. It is a fact of life that, on the levels of contamination in our beef, a person has to consume seven bullocks a day in order to get a toxic chemical dose. That is how ridiculous most of this nonsense is that is talked about our beef. We produce the best and the cleanest grass-fed beef in the world. Every other country that produces beef houses the stock for six months of the year and hand feeds it grain. These residues are found in that grain, whereas we grass feed our cattle. Those of us at Maranoa and other electorates, such as Gippsland, produce wonderful beef.
